name: Papers, Please
description: Congratulations. The October labor lottery is complete. Your name was pulled. For immediate placement, report to the Ministry of Admission at Grestin Border Checkpoint. An apartment will be provided for you and your family in East Grestin. Expect a Class-8 dwelling.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP or later Processor: 1.5 GHz Core2Duo Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: OpenGL 1.4 or better Storage: 100 MB available space Additional Notes: Minimum 1280x720 screen resolution

reviews.review_text: Papers, Please has no right to be as fun as it is. Papers, Please has no right to be as poignant as it is. Papers, Please has no right to be possibly the best PC game of 2013 I've played. Papers, Please is all of these things.  The gameplay of Papers, Please is more or less a tedium simulator. It's Paperwork: The Game. And yet, you know that you need to process as many of these poor people as you can so that your family won't starve. You know that the old lady who you just denied will probably never see her son again; you know the young man you just let through has less than glorious ambitions in your city. Will you support the rebels? Will you toe the party line? Will you let the young lady through, even though her passport is clearly fake, because her fiance was just before her and bribed you to do so? The choice in this game is staggering, and the simplicity of the game itself allows for complete assimilation of your mind into the mind of your character. You feel bad when your child gets sick, but you know that food is sometimes more important than heat.  Papers, Please is a work of video game brilliance - a work of art. I give it seven out of seven stars.

Two years ago I was detained on my way into America. I was taken away from the line, seperated from my passport and dumped in a bleak empty room filled with lines of chairs and people in various states of distress. Nobody told me what was happening. Occasionally an agent would appear at the back of the room and give passports to some of the people waiting, who left quickly and quietly. At one point an elderly man went up to the desk and begged to be let through, to be met with ice-cold condescension.  After about half an hour I was called through into the back room. There I was told to sit down in front of a man called Keane, on a desk filled with papers. Keane never looked at me. He asked where I was going and why I was going there. When I said I was visiting my girlfriend he leered and asked me if it was 'true love'. When I asked him whether I'd been pulled out of the line for a reason or if it was a random check, he told me it 'wasn't random'. When I asked him if I would make my flight in 20 minutes, he told me that it depended how fast I could run.  Eventually Keane gave me my passport back and told me to 'lift my heels up'. I missed my flight by minutes. I waited for an hour for the next flight and then another hour on the plane for it to take off.  This game made me feel sorry for Keane.  10/10, would feel empathy against my will again

Papers Please is just awesome. It's a game where you play an immigration inspector. No, that's not meant sarcastically. I know it sounds dull, but let me tell you that it is absolutely not. It's challenging and interesting, even if the game lasts just a few hours.   With every level you play new challenges are unlocked and near the end of the game you have to take into consideration the many aspects of an inspection.  There are many moral choices to be made and in total there are 20 endings so there's also more than enough replayabily. An endless mode is also included so this game is neverending. You could play this game your whole life and not get bored. Ok, maybe after a few years you'd get bored, but theoretically you could just go on and on.  The graphics have a retro Russian vibe that really impressed me. And the soundtrack isn't very long, but what's there is very good. The song that was played during the credits was actually great.  In the end Papers Please was a delight to play. If only more games had gameplay this fun and an idea this original. Get this as soon as you have some money.  Glory to Arstotzka !  [Rating: 90/100]

Papers, Please is one of those games where you go in expecting to not like it. The graphics are retro (terrible compared to most other games available today), the controls overly simplistic, the music very repetitive. There are no voice actors; every conversation is shown by moving text bubbles. Finally, there is only one setting and you are completely stationary.   Put all of the above together and you would think that this is one of the most terrible games of the decade. But you would be wrong. Despite its simplicity, despite its repetitiveness, this is one of the most in depth, thought provoking games I've played in years. And with 20 different endings, there is plenty of replayability.  If you haven't played this game, you're missing out.

You're working in the booth one day, and you receive a note. The note tells you that there's a serial killer in line today, and that he's killed a man's son. That man is line behind him. The note implores you to let this killer into the country, so that the man can find him and take revenge for his son. Or, you can detain the killer and have him taken by the police.  However, on top of all this, you have a sick family at home. Your own son is very ill and you need money for food and medicine. You could be seriously penalized for letting EITHER of these men through if they don't have proper paperwork. Hell, do you even know if the man will be able to CATCH this killer? What if he fails? You'll have let a murderer walk freely into the country.  You have to make a decision quickly because any time you waste means less money for your family.  This is the kind of scenario you deal with in this game. At first it feels like just the bleak observational game where you just look at paperwork and allow/deny access. But as the game goes on, you'll be presented with these moral quandries that really test you. Any decision you make, be it morally good or bad, saintly or selfish, could have a range of consequences. Which winds up making the game incredibly curious and makes you want to keep going to see what happens.
>Hot Lady comes up to booth (Found true love) >Gives passport >Gender is stated as male >Screens her >Very hot woman is a very hot guy  -Denied-  10/10

A concept that is basically running immigration for an eastern-bloc country during the cold war. Sounds boring as hell, right? So deceitful it is then, because few things are more addicting. While playing, I kept finding myself thinking 'Just one more day, one more then off to bed'. Five hours later, it's 5AM and I'm due at work in three hours. No regrets here, either. The gameplay is simple but deep, and the story branches like a visual novel. Plus it's the only game I've ever played to truly make me actually feel -BAD- for doing what the game tells me to. Video game history teaches us that morality is black and white. Papers reveals how evoke it with more gray area than I ever thought a game could, and it's crazy how easily it does so.  There's a reason this game was voted GoTY by so many publications, and touted as simply amazing by gamers far and wide. Quirky, fun, addictive - you owe it to yourself to play this gem. GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!

'Papers, please.' [See a discrepancy] [Ask to the owner of the papers] 'That is new to me.' 'Denied!' * pop * [Person goes away] 'NEXT!'    Papers, Please  is the one of the best game I've ever played. You and your family are moving to Arstotzka, a fictional country in the east Europe, and you are responsible for monitoring the border.  With the 'simple' premisse to verify fake passports, you must to be attentive, any miss and you will be notified and after two notifications, the next will be deducted from your paycheck. Still, you need to pay the bills, like the house rent, heating, food for your family and, if necessary, medicines.  The best part of the game is the immersion, you feel like you are in the game. At any time, a unexpected event can happen and you must to do something - will you let pass a woman that, if she returns to her home country, she will die? Or how you react if a misterious guy needs your help? The game has several endings. Any choice that you do, it will influence throughout the history.   Papers, Please  is a unique and indispensable game.

This game is all about speed and attention, if you lack one of those then you might be in trouble.  Papers please puts you to verify passports, it may sound boring but it turns out to be really nice. At first you can approve only people from your country, after a day you can approve anyone that shows eligible to enter but there's a thing there, you need to verify discrepancies such as gender, emission date, etc.   You earn money for every person you get it right, allowing to enter or denying it's passage will earn you money if you get it right but if you make a mistake you will be penalized for it, the money is used to pay your apartment rent and to buy food for your family, yes you have a family in this game. This is where speed and attention comes to play, if you lack speed then you won't attend to many 'costumers', making you earn less money and if you lack attention and don't detect the discrepancies then you will get penalized for the people that either enters without being allowed or deny the ones that are clear to pass, easy, right?  Each day the game will get harder and harder but it will offer you new ways to deal with those people, just calm yourself down to do a good job and pay attention to every detail, and remember, glory to Arstotzka.

Quite a game. Everybody in the reviews is talking about the choices it puts you through, so I'll try to be a little different.  The game is so simple, yet complex at the same time. As you advance you have more paperwork, more stuff to check, you have to pay attention to every tiny detail and you can still see that stupid paper coming on your desk saying 'oh you didn't verify that, it was incorrect'. You have to manage money and juggle with it if you can't be fast at going through the people in line.  I really like how there are different outcomes, coming from your choices and everything you did. There is not really a story behind the game on its own. It's not about the inspector, not about the paperwork, not about the people in line. It's about it as a whole. As I've seen somewhere, very well pointed out, it can be compared to the Wall of Berlin.  Anyway. If you come here expecting a lot of action, I will be pretty straight forward with you. There is not much action and the gameplay is slow-paced. I still recommend this, though, it is a nice game and really gets your concentration on point.
I rate this a GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA/10.

These things seem obvious to anyone who has lived in a post-soviet country, but apparently Americans are shocked by this game. Very good indie game, though it's more of a story actually. It's hard to imagine, but processing papers can get boring at times, I know.  Nevertheless the creator has done a fantastic job. The effect on me wasn't as strong because I've actually seen it first hand in places like Ukraine.

One popular criticism of this game is that it is unbelievably boring. These people are missing the point.  Yes, this game is unlike many other video games because it is poignant and is attempting to make some very serious social commentary.  Briefly, you are a customs agent for a country vaguely reminiscent of Cold War era Russia. Your job is to check the paperwork of all people attempting to enter your country. Those who check out are permitted to enter and the rest are either rejected or detained.  Your job is only part of the story. After work every day you struggle to provide food, heat, and medicine for your family. You can make more money if you process paperwork faster but this often results in mistakes and fines threatening to send you into debt or worse.  This game is not like a restaurant worker simulator because it has a clear message. Well, even the restaurant simulators are maybe suggesting you have some empathy for overworked servers.  This game makes a more serious point: Border crossings are dehumanizing for both those attempting to cross as well as for the employees. Those travelling are subject to invasive searches, embarassing questions, endless lines, and the potential for political violence against their persons. The employees in turn begin to treat the travellers not as humans but as cattle or a meal ticket. These workers must carry out the often arbitrary regulations of their country in a way that often divides famliers and destroys lives.  This is not a game that one can play forever. It is good for a couple play throughs and maybe a little exploration of the bonus modes. It does not take very long to get to the heart of this game. After a short time of playing you will start to feel hollow inside. And that is the point.  I cannot think of a game that has engaged the hearts and minds of players to contemplate very real political problems in this way. In closing, the game is not fun. The game is terrible. And this is the point.
Don't accept the $1000 and $2000.  Don't.  Do.  IT.

Recommended:  A strangely-compelling game, Papers Please tells an intriguing story of a backwater communist nation through the medium of passports and dialogue. A little rough in the graphics, albeit intentionally so, and a bit of a niche game given the subject matter, but there really is no game like this one and on that token alone, it is assuredly worth giving a look. Just watch out for a bit of a difficulty wall to press past, towards the end of the game.   Read the full review on Highland Arrow  here  [www.highlandarrow.com]

Not in a million years did I think a game this simple could be so fun. Being a boarder security guard just reached another level of awesomeness.   Just as the trailer shows you check passports - but it gets progressively harder over the course of time, not to mention interesting. The trailer literally nails what the game is about and does a good job of it. I found myself playing for an hour easily the first time I played. It literally delivers what it is designed to and isn't meant for a person who cannot sit still and analyze the finer details required to meet the games challenge demands. I like it as it forces me to pay attention. There are surprises in the game and nothing works exactly as it's supposed to. You may be offered a bribe half way through the game, and if you take it, you may get away with it. However, you may get caught down the line and then thrown in prison. Subsequently, you must try your best to keep your family alive. Money pays for heat and health needs of the family. Upgrades are also available for the booth, as well as your dwelling. You will run into an assortment of characters (to say the least) that will keep you on your toes.   Graphics are basic. Is this bad? Not at all as the person who did the designs was extremely careful in what they were trying to achieve. Sounds do not have much of a variation, but I guarantee you'll be repeating what the guy on the loud speaker says every time you click it.   This is most likely the only indie game I ever recommend to friends. Papers, Please may seem like a boring game - you sit and check documents and stamp passports. Who would've thought it may be fun? But it is. You have choice in this game. You decide to split a family, because of expired passport or to let them in at the cost of losing your paycheck and having no money for food and medicine. You may decide to help overturn a tyrannical government... or better not risk your life. Papers, Please is more about moral choice than about stamping passports. Story and climate of this game are great. Definitely worth trying.  Glory to Arstotzka!
Different game that's worth to play! Fun and Interesting, love it!

Papers Please is a point-and-click simulation in where the player uses investigative skills in looking at papers. The gameplay is monotonous, dull, and repetitive, thus truly simulating the work of a border immigrations officer. If the papers are inaccurate you decline, if papers are accurate you accept. The player receives money based on performance to pay for amenities at home, then the next day begins.   The nation’s immigrations policy changes, and so do the people you service; the stories are told from the glimpses of a small border entry. You, the player, the insignificant being of the grand scheme of things, play a cog in the clockwork that this game has created. Your seemingly insignificant choices influence the multiple families and organizations through a simple choice between red or green stamp.    This game is not for everyone. It is not grossly fun, flamboyant, or explosive. But I recommend it for those seeking something more than just a cheesy dramatization or a shooter.

This is the most gripping bureaucracy simulation game I can possibly imagine. I've never played anything like it. It's so simple and so elegant, and it still manages to have one of the most compelling non-traditional narratives I've experienced.

'Paperwork? how can that be fun?'  This game really took me by surprise, I never thought paperwork and immigration control could make such a fun game!  Basically, you are in an fictional east-european country, you are responsible for who comes into Arstotzka and who doesn't, as the days go on it gets more complicated and people will ask you for favors, there will be terrorist attacks, you need to maintain your family and much more, how you do all these things will determine how the game will end for you.  I would highly reccomend gatting this game!

I haven't reviewed this yet? Well, it's overdue then.   Papers, Please  is simply a MUST HAVE on Steam. Especially if you like to try your hand at beurocratic tasks in a video game in an exciting way. It's monotonous, but enjoyable. I know it's less than 20 hours to get 100%, but I logged in (at the time of this writing) at least 43 hours of gameplay. It's that good.  You play as an unknown inspector who was elected through a lottery to work   as a security guard running a graveyard shift at Freddy Fazbear's pizzeria for 5 nights  as a border inspector between the cursed Kolechia and the wonderous motherland Arstotzka for one month. But you have a time limit in which you can work, which adds pressure to your performance. Inspect more and provide the correct responses quickly to get paid more. Make mistakes and it'll come out of your paycheck after 2 free warnings a day. By the end of the day, you'll need to pay for rent, food (optional), heat (optional), medical bills (optional if heat or food is neglected), and various other opportunities. You play as a father providing for your family. If your family dies (or other conditions occur), the game is over. It's also a plus that it throws in ethical dillemas to keep you on your toes.  People say this game is communistic and I'd say I agree with their statements. You are playing in a job you did not choose and are dissuaded from trying to make more than you actually do...which makes it understandable why people would take bribes in communistic or socialist countries.  There are various paths you can take to different endings. You can choose to complete your tasks in a purely beaurocratic manner for the motherland Arstotzka, you can help aid in a revolution for the Order of the EZIC Star, or you can escape Arstotzka by moving away with forged passports. The fate of the people, the nation, and your family are in your hands.   PROS: Addicting gameplay Great (yet simple) story Great challenges Nice Puzzles (if you choose to work for EZIC) Implementation of ethical dillemas No bugs Randomized portraits and stats based on a database (great programming) Arstotzka (Joke pro. XD)  CONS: Limited music choices No planned sequel at this point Can be infuriating if you make mistakes Not all moral/ethical choices are judged/rewarded May be too bland/boring/monotonous to some (Not for me, but there are times where it can feel dull) Kolechia (Okay, that's a joke con. Just making sure you're reading these. lol)   This game is a great experience that seems simplistic, yet is so much more. You can lose yourself for hours at a time playing this game. I cannot say whether or not it's worth full price, but if it is on sale, you would have to be crazy to not grab it. This game truly competes with 'Triple A' First Party companies and proves that indies can be great things.   9/10 Glory to Arstotzka!

What a genuine diamond in the rough. This game captures the monotonous tone of a dead-end job and stylises it to perfection. I really appreciate the little things Lucas Pope snuck in for replay value and just the funny little side-happening which occur now and again, not to mention the suspense of working to earn a pay for your family.  Another thing that really clicks with Papers, Please and I is the genuine question towards morals and work. Do you let a senile, old woman through the checkpoint after pleading and begging for your mercy? At the cost of your entire career? Or do you deny her, sending her to a one-way trip to absolutely no-where.  Either way, I loved this game, it really knew how to get to me. Rating: 8.8/10 Personal Rating: 'Modern Art' Ranking on Top 10: 4.

Papers, Please is a fun simulation game in which you play as an immigration border patrol agent for a Communist government. You have a book of rules and it is your job to either approve or deny citizens. If there is a discrepancy between the rules and their passport or paperwork, you have to interrogate them. Upon interrorgation, you can detain them (like if they have weapons or forged papers) or let them through. There are some moralistic choices along the way. For instance, one husband has all the correct paperwork, but his wife is next in line with missing paperwork. Do you let her through and risk a citation or deny her because of the rules?   As the game progresses, there are more and more information you have to keep an eye on. Even the tiniest error can glaze over your eyes like mismatched gender and weight on the paperwork. The game may seem 'boring and repititive,' but that is the point of the game. It's suppposed to simulate a boring, real life job. There is also a secret organization that tries to take down the government and you can choose to participate with them or not. Papers, Please has a great sense of humor with 20 different endings and memorable characters. In order to attain a better apartment for your family as well as food and heat, you have to process people faster and correctly to make more money.   'Glory to Arstotzka!'

For as simple of an idea as border control, Papers, Please offers a suprisingly deep story alongside a simple, but effective interface. An idea that should be repetitive instead becomes unpredictable and keeps you on your toes.

What can I say as a review for this game? It is mindbendingly fun for me. It is overwhelmingly inspired and unique. It has been a year or more now that I have owned this game and I still cannot master it. I cannot stress enough the brain power required just to stay ahead of the bank in this game. This game should be the test to graduate college and failure should deport you ^^.   NOTE: not for kids Ignore this game at your own peril.

In a world where many people don't realize a 'visa' isn't always a credit card, Papers Please seems like a pretty odd concept. A game where you stamp passports, being careful to abide by the ever-increasing rules and regulations of your dystopian public employers that are subject to the hopeless political climate of your war-torn and espionage-filled region, tends to stand out amongst the current plethora of green-lit retro platformers.   Despite my own life-long love for a good sidescroller, I have to say Papers Please is the most engrossed I've been in a game in quite a while. When you're not lost in the bureaucratic fever dream of scanning each and every entrant's documentation - of which more and more will be required as time goes on and governments play dirtier - you're juggling funds for your family's food, heat, medicine, and possibility of moving up from the 'Class-8' dwellings that sound only a notch better than homelessness.   What's more, it comes as no surprise that those around you are looking to do the same; almost each day of the game has someone with missing or faulty documentation and an excuse to go along with it. Reuniting two long-lost loves, aiding an underground resistance group, allowing a woman on death-row in her home country with no documentation to enter with her allowed husband, allowing a child serial killer in (rather than detaining him) so a vengeful father of a little girl can exercise his own justice, and the repeated attempts of a happy-go-lucky drug dealer who tries entering with a crayon passport are all decisions left up to you, keeping in mind the 2-citation limit you get per day before being docked much-needed pay.  And honestly, when you see a citation pop up that wasn't on purpose, that ♥♥♥♥ing fax-machine sound and a pink slip popping up? Your heart ♥♥♥♥ing sinks. You feel like an idiot. And worst of all, who knows what sort of scumbag you just let into the country scot-free after a long day of rejecting numerous people whose intentions and needs were possibly far more innocent than their lack of documents would suggest.   Still, the game has its faults. 'Booth upgrades' are simple hotkeys to make your job a smidge faster that many seem to not want to use anyway. The sound leaves a lot to be desired - there's basically 3 gibberish-y voice lines that are reused throughout each line of dialog ('baebaz', 'hiyakku', 'oushtod'), the game has a nearly overwhelming amount of endings (many of which feel more like a depressing Game-Over than an ending), and some things like the benefits of upgrading your apartment are poorly explained.  But play this game, and be mindful about it. Don't fall into the the ♥♥♥♥ing 'Glory to Arstotzka!' memespouting ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, don't treat it like Dystopian Despot Simulator XDDD 2013 and then toss it away without trying the other playstyles, and think about how immigration, customs, and bureaucracy affect you and all those in the world for better or worse, right down to the individual working at the desk.
Arstotzka number one country
Done a side quest.  Got lots of money for services rendered.  Didn't move out quick enough.  Neighbours reported my wealth.  Had money confiscated.  Was arrested.   10/10

I'm not sure why I'd even bother to write a review for this one, because you already know if you want it. Either you're intrigued by the concept, curious just how they can manage to make such a boring idea into compelling action, or you're instantly repelled by the premise, and rightfully so. This is about as indie as indie games get, and also as brilliant as they get. It takes such a simple thing, and wraps it up in politics, real-world parallels, and perhaps even some genuine feels to make you feel more invested in the fate of a fictional immigration officer than you ever would about a generic grimacing action hero.   But drama and intelligence aside, it's also surprisingly fun, with a very smooth difficulty curve that makes you feel your own skills improving just enough to meet the game's increasing demands. It even comes with some bonus high score modes that you could conceivably see yourself playing. It tells an interesting, branching story through simple means while also somehow managing to make boring real life work into entertainment I want more of. This is pretty much the epitome of why I love the indie game market despite all its warts.

'Papers, Please' is not easy to describe. It isn't what most people would consider a traditional game. There are no points, and winning or losing isn't as black-and-white as you may be used to. You could categorize it as a bureaucracy simulator or an everyday survival game, and that wouldn't necessarily be wrong, but it would definitely miss the point. 'Papers, Please' is — at its heart — an adventure game.  Though everything takes place from within a tiny border checkpoint, the game's drama and tension all comes from the decisions you're forced to make. You'll never feel more anxious stamping a piece of virtual paper than you will when playing this game. You will legitimately hate your supervisor, and you might even care about the people who pass through your little booth.  TL;DR: Get this game if you're looking for insightful, clever political commentary.

Once again, another staggeringly unique title is pulled out of the seemingly endless hat of indie game concepts. This time in the form of a disturbingly farmiliar dystopian society known as Arstotzka. While it may seem like the monotonous, dull drone of endlessly stamping passports; Papers, Please is a game of moral conflict. In the world of Papers, Please, you play as an unnamed protagonist, a mid level beaurocrat, working in a border checkpoint that seems like a parallel to East and West Berlin in the 80s. We can only assume these countries are roughly based on the Soviet Union or other Soviet influenced republics. The graphic style has an appropriately grey and muddled appearance that fits the situation very well. The gameplay is deliberately dull, which may be difficult for some to appreciate. As you go down the line, you begin to work in a rhythm. As you gain this rhythm you have satisfaction for catching frauds and it becomes fun in a droning, dull way. Later into the game you may look up, horrified, and realized that you have become a cog in the machine. You have begun processing people and are shocked with how you can dehumanize them in such a way. Sometimes you want to help others, but your family is still barely hovering above the poverty line. How can you keep them alive without accepting bribes or perhaps sending a poor traveller back to their home country where they will die because they do not have the correct papers? That is the beauty of Papers, Please or better yet, that is what is ugly and disgusting about Papers, Please; but we love it so.

When I first turned on Papers, Please...I wasn't sure what to expect, I hadn't watched any videos about the game or even read very much about it. It was a Humble Bundle pack-in and I thought it might be interesting.  I was absolutely right. Papers, Please is easily one of my top games of ALL TIME. The gameplay begins as simple, but gradually becomes more and more challenging as the game carries forward. Small subplots twist and turn the otherwise very straightforward storyline...  There is a good chunk of comedy relief as well (Lolibutts loves you Jorgi), and a little heartstring pulling here and there.   There are also 20 different endings. Which is pretty damn cool if you ask me. Overall, I'd say give this game a try if you're in the mood to try something 'Different'. It can get frustrating at times when the slightest detail was overlooked and costs you credits or just ups your citation count...but luckily you can always replay the day later.   Addicting, fun, and just plain original. Glory to Astolska.   9/10

Papers Please is a DAMN addictive game for something that doesn't look fun in concept.  You have to constantly check for discrepencies to make sure you're not punished. When you're trying to get as many people approved (or denied) to feed your family and keep them warm, it gets really stress inducing.  I HIGHLY recommend this game to everyone who like this type of game...

This is a very interesting game. The depressive world and story mixed with that intense music, a game i've never played before. It's very difficult and challenging, it requires all your concentration to not miss a tiny detail on any of the given papers; this game is for open-minded people who like very challenging, brain straining games. I really enjoyed the flow of the game, and loved the story changing characters, which appear ever so often, as well as all the other little details put in it. While intensly working on checking data from the papers, you always have to be ready for a terrorist attack or some other event which may come unexpected. I also especially like the moral choices (which do not have influence on the story), for example, will you accept the wife to get to her husband even though she doesnt't have correct data? Will you accept bribes for people with not enough money to get the needed papers? Then there are bigger decisions that may change the complete story of the game, which I will not give an example for, because they might contain big spoilers.   This game is definitely worth checking out, if you don't want to buy it, you might as well check out some videos on the web.

If you want to feel like Rainman, play this game. Detaining a guy because you found one letter out of place amongst his four different pieces of paperwork is brilliant. However, it's also harrowing, considering this is Arztotska and the man you detained will likely never be seen again.

Papers, Please is the game that made me think I'm a terrible person. This game simulates a life in a totalitarian regime where you work on the border, deciding people's lives. If you do good and let people who don't have a passport but want to go over the border continue, your pay will be deducted. If you don't have money, your family will starve, and if you don't have money to pay the bills you will be arrested. On the other hand, if you don't help the people you will feel like you are a terrible person. I made this mistake once in the game, and never again. I destroyed their regime, saved my family, but alas my son has died. I would recommend this game to everyone to check their moral codex, and especially to people in rich countries, so they can know what is like living in poverty.

Many games and companies claim to be inovated or trying to push the norm and being progressive. In the past Nintendo were the biggest innovators pushing the gaming industry with new ideas on how to play video games. The past few years the gaming industry has seen little to almost no new ideas since the wii came to store shelves. All of this is important because you won't see innovation from some big company; you will find it from some indie developer called Lucas Pope. A man who used to work for Naughty Dog Studios working on the beaten to death series Uncharted broke free and decided to do his own thing.   This game just surprised me from every aspect and I just wanted more and more. The gameplay consist of reading things carefully and making sure everything matches to what it is supposed to be. If things don't match or seem fishy you will deny or detain a person. Sounds easy at first but you must do all this under a strict clock. You get money for every person you deny or pass, but you do thing wrong and you get fined for it. And you need this money to pay rent, feed your family, keep them warm, and healthy. You can barely get enough money to do all of these things for your family. You need to manage your money very carefully.    This game is maybe one of the best games I played in my life. It is so different and original and it does it all in such a fantastic way. I highly reccomend everyone to play this game if you ever get the chance. I only wish more games to take such new approaches to gameplay can come out sooner.

Will you feel sorry for those you have fallen or hard times? Or is your families well being more important. Papers, Please tests your human morals to new levels.  Amazing game. Great story highly recommend.

You're a border inspector for the Great Nation of Arstotzka, and all you will do all day is check the papers of travelers who are seeking entry into the country. In the beginning, all you have to do is check for one or two things. By the end, there's a massive list of potential things that could be wrong with some of the paperwork. When I tried it, I understood. It's extraordinarily fun. I can't recommend it enough. This is certainly not a review about the game itself. We ALL know how great it is.  I'm here to talk about the quality of its Linux port. I'm not surprised that an indie title has flawless support so far, compared to certain AAA titles I will not mention right now.  Everything works as you'd expect, display, input, audio... no major problems. There's just a rare issue with certain lines of text having a whole row of pixels chopped off, but it doesn't affect readability (if it happens on Windows too, then it's all ok).  PS: I like the fact on fullscreen it uses nearest neighbor interpolation and keeps pixels square. I'm kind of a sucker for that.

Papers, Please is a thoughtful, oddly enjoyable, and surprisingly funny game. It's brisk without feeling superficial, so you can get as much out of it as you like without devoting a month of your life just to get through the story. Highly recommended if your looking for a game that's totally different from the mainstream.

You have to buy this game, there's no option about it, if you have the money just buy it right now!  This game forces you into a situation where you have to do your job near-perfectly to get enough money for your family to survive and be happy, but that involves screwing over a lot of helpless people in situations similar to yours! Will you work hard, not questioning the authorities and provide for your family; or do you make a sacrifice to help the common folk? That's up to you! A lot of other things go on, but I'll leave you to discover that because it's pretty mind blowing on your first play through! (As the game says, it's a Thriller)  The gameplay is also surprisingly fun for a game about checking over paperwork, it involves a lot of thought and skill! It is extremely unique and it constantly throws new rules onto your job based on the events that happen in the game world, changing up the gameplay and making it more interesting day by day!   The game also has a lot of replay value, with many different endings you can achieve and lots of different ways the story can drive forward based on your choices each day. You can replay any day or start a completely new game at any time without losing the progress of later days, so they give you full freedom to experiment and retry when things don't go how you wanted them to!   You see all these people saying that video games can't be an art form, and this game can't be further from the truth. After playing this, no one could deny that video games are an art form. Just buy it now because you'll love it and you need to support true innovative and artistic games. BUY IT! I'm waiting...  Bought it yet? No? Why the f*** not!?

While the first glimpse says to a store-wanderer ''boring, boring, boring'', this idea is completely false. Papers, Please is the complete opposite of boring.  Taking place in a fictional   semi-corrupt semi-just-want-MIA-members-kept-in-place   country named Arstotzka, you play as a border control agent, accepting or denying job-seekers, immigrants and criminals. While this game's first few hours/minutes (depending on how quick your fingers are and how long it takes to strain them dragging documents around your messy desk) are quite dull, the people I saw in just that little amount of gameplay made me rage, laugh and stare. This is a brilliant attribute as it jolts the brain and your emotions to a flying start. Time to time the game gets harder and more time-consuming, but still follows the same laugh-rage experience. It also displays attributes of a shooter - you will sometimes see a terrorist attack and have the power to stop one at your protagonist's twiddling fingers.   It also gives you opinions and puzzles   (including the bomb some idiot thought would kill off an inspector and all the guards surrounding him)  , like managing your expenses and doing whatever it takes to not be arrested for giving a single document to the police. While this isn't too frequent it still makes you happy there's a change in the game and you have some freedom.   Graphics-wise the game is pixellated, but looks lovely at the same time. This style fits the time the game was set, as I just thought, considering it is set in the 80s, a time when 8-bits were first introduced. It also displays musical talent, and the theme makes me want to go on a march in synchronization with it.   So, overall, I'd say Papers, Please, from such a simple idea, turns out to be one of my favourite games of all time, and I congratulate Dukope for making such a brilliant game.  10/10. Glory to Arstotzka.
Papers, Please offers a unique gameplay experience soaked in humour. It's much more than a customs officer simulator. It brings a new perspective to game design. A must play.

Start playing this game and think it's easy. Spend 5 minutes in it and realise you're not paying attention, so you get a notice from the government. Begin to spend more time on details. The day is over. Notice how you earn less money because you took too much to inspect so few people. Basic needs like food and rent need to be paid. Get to work again and rush more people. Make mistakes; The government is all over you.  This game is amazingly fun and a real exercise to your brain.Try to memorise all the provinces of the different countries (good luck) and the game will tip you off your chair with more government rules. Though some things are easy to check once you get the hang of it, when pressure starts to build up the game will break your concentration with some hilarious comments, love stories or pure eyebrow rising momments from the immigrants.  All in all, this game has simple repeat step X and Y to achieve goal, but all of those steps may or may not come for each of the immingrants you need to inspect, and even if they appear, they will be in a random order. This is what really makes you think.   The game has Story Mode and Endless Mode. You will also have an option to enable 'easy mode'.

This is one of the most unique games to come around in many years. A cold war based theme set in 1982 where you decide on the entrance of people into your country, the 'Glorious' Arstotzka. The game difficulty starts slowly as you check the validity of people's documents at the border. This continues to build as more complex events occur adding more and more information to verify and new methods to test the stories of the masses. At the end of the work day, you are paid by how many people you processed and penalized for mistakes made. Your money is used to support your family, providing as good a living as you can for the necessities of life: Rent, food, heat, medicine. It is a serious challege to process as many as you can while not letting criminals, terrorists, and other 'undesirables' into your country.  A word about the graphics: they are intentionally low end to give the feel for what games were back in the 80's. Nevertheless, what gamers often times fail to remember, it is the imagination that is the most important piece of play. Many of you will recall how the BEST and most fun you had as a kid was when you had a tree branch sword, a pine cone grenade, or a fort made of boxes. This frame of mind is nearly lost on the current generation as graphics have all but stunted their ability to dream and pretend. This game deserves a look for the price, currently $5. Those of you who remember the cold war era will laugh at the feel of the game, while those who do not may find that they actually have a great time with it as they strengthen 'the muscle of their imagination' that has been dormant for perhaps their whole lives. Glory to Arstotzka!

With over 20 hi-standard awards achieved already, Papers, Please is seriously ONE OF THE GREATEST GAMES published in 2013.  It's old-school, it's innovative, also imo beautiful in a classic way in its brutally simple appeareance and it made me laugh out loud few times (can't remember when single-player made me actually laugh :D). The concept itself is let alone just brilliant but when laced with a great storytelling in which player can impact and with a gameplay that enhances the back-to-the-childhood feeling you get, Papers, Please is one to remeber. Just the ancient-sounding theme music brings an amused grin to your face - a reminder of the good old times. This is not easy game by any means, requires some brains and sharp eye but not in an annoying way. I found the difficulty very fitting and enjoyable.   Papers, Please may not offer something to play for a very long time right away (depends on person), that said it will surely exceed its value by far anyway in the hands of an average gamer. On the other hand I can see myself returning to this game in future, similarly as with e.g. Max Payne, DOOM, etc. I do not want to give spoilers - one's has to experience this game like it happens in it's story - out of the blue. As I fancy 2013 not a great year regarding to game releases I am glad I have now something to remember and to recommend to fellow gamers.   Glory to Arstotzka!

OK, so I'm sure that when you are reading this review, that you are probably sceptical about getting this game. I think, though, that this game is worth buying for a multitude of reasons. This game requires the player to be very observant. I find it interesting that everything you do in this game affects the story line. I do recommend this game for people who like the Stanely Parable and other strategy games. Do you like paper? Hate people? This is the game for you! This thrilling, hyper-realistic paper pushing game includes miles and miles of paper-handling. From manuals, to passports, to municipally-issued identification slips, to photo-ids, to so much more! Not just paper, though; stamps. That's right, you get to STAMP your papers. Red and green colors! But mostly the red. Well, if you like the color red, it's a plus! Not only that, you get the hate of an entire population (or so it feels) directed at you for denying them passage into the glorious Arstotzka. And you get to hate them back by denying them even more, those filthy heathens!  Well, to wrap this up in a way those who don't like reading will understand, (TL;DR:) 'Papers, Please' is a great game. Especially if you like paper.
A great game giving you lots of choices and lots of fun!

I would say the subtitle of 'dystopian document thriller' is partly correct. The setting and mechanics in this game are fairly unique I think, where you play a border agent in a country with an oppressive government.  The gameplay itself is actually fairly routine, and can be summarized as rule memorization and observation skills. This is fine, as it works and makes sense within the story. The sound design and aesthetic lend to this very well. There were no performance issues.  I don't think there is that much replayability to the story despite the variety of endings. There is an unlockable endless mode, which could make this fun as a pastime too Still, I'd reccomend this game for its unique experience. Its really not something you see every day.

I'm not sure how much this normally costs, but i got it for 2.99. I think its worth it for that price, but only for certain people. This game is not a game about 'Points' or 'How fast can i do this'. this game is where you have to take care of your family on a salary barely enough for your rent, but its a lot more than that. You have to make choices that affect not only you, but the world around you as well. There are choices you make that match risk with reward, and there are choices where you must decided in between this person and your family. Every error you make gets a citation, and after two citations, you get docked payment. People ask you to smuggle them out of the city, but doing so can get your payment docked. This can be very bad for your family. They might beg you or tell you that they will die if they don't get out of the city. You can't do anything unless your willing to sacrifice your family. As for morals, you can accept bribes that can help you, but at a cost. I apologize if this reveiw is all-over-the-place, but this game really is a good game.
Highly addictive game that is well worth the money. This is one of the few games that I enjoyed completing multiple times to get all of the different endings.

The banality of evil shown beautifully. And nothing is more banal than powerless beaurcratic simulation. I guess, it's technically a puzzle game. Yet somehow, despite its subject matter, it's compelling and pleasing to play. Papers, Please is one of the best pieces of sociopolitical commentary in games. It is /the best/ example of mechanics-as-message I can think of.   I don't know if you'll like it, but you should play it: it's astonishing. And if you're games designer, it should be mandatory. There's no quick time events here, chief.

This game is way more fun than it should be. Players take on the role of an immigration worker, checking passports and other paperwork at the border of a fictional country called Arstotzka. Your job is to make sure their paperwork is in order, and either let them pass into Arstotzka or turn them away. While this may sound like a simple, boring concept, it quickly becomes quite difficult, and the story kept me intrigued enough to keep playing long after it should have gotten boring. Players must balance duty with morality, while trying to bring in enough money to take care of the worker's starving, sick and cold family. Terrorists strike, family members die, and all along the way you must perform your job or risk being terminated. The simplistic 8-bit style graphics are not distracting: actually, they seem to add to the dreary, mundane atmosphere, allowing you to more fully immerse yourself in the dystopian world. There is a bit of comic relief (GLORY TO COBRASTAN!!!) but even with the minor comic relief, this game is dark and depressing in the most perfect way. It really makes the player think about society and political problems in a communist state, bringing up deep questions about humanity under the guise of a simple game. Definitely a must-play.  --------------------------------------------------------------------  If you enjoy my reviews, why not follow my curation page?  Click here to do that thing!

Addictive gameplay in this one, you play as an immigration officer on the border of fictional pseudo-communist-eastern block country of Arstotzka. Every day you must check immigrants' IDs, permits, work passes and so on, trying to not let down your superiors and in the meantime taking home as much money as possible, even by being corrupted, in order to guarantee your family food, heat and medicines.  Every day new regulations are established and being fast, without committing errors, checking every single document with the right tools, is really hard and stressful, but really fun!! 20 different endings are available, together with many unpredictable twists, and include mysterious plots uncovered, breakaways to foreign and safer countries, terrorists attacks, personal richness and so on.  Technically is a really basic game, but Papers, Please strengths reside in its peculiar mechanics, it was a really nice surprise and I would suggest it to anyone interested in something fresh and unique, easy to learn but difficult to master, a good example of ideas winning over graphics awesomeness!

The game also makes you face countless moral dilemmas (accepting bribes, not allowing a husband to follow his wife due to missing a document, strip searching someone due to questionable gender), and really gives you a great amount of choice, with over 20 possible endings. I think starting the game is probably the hardest part, in that you are thinking 'am I really spending my free time validating hypothetical paperwork'? But I think once you get past those thoughts, you can immerse yourself into a very powerful and profound experience that is hard to find in gaming.

Cold War era Eastern Bloc customs agent sim...  Surprisingly enjoyable and thought provoking gameplay. The game is basically your doing identification checks on people trying to get admission into your country. You have to balance speed and accuracy of your check-ins, deal with daily bureacratic rule changes in processes, and try to keep your family alive on rations, or risk accepting bribes.
Papers, Please is more fun than you can imagine. I wouldn't want to work in a real border checkpoint, but the one in Arstotzka is an exception.

Games provide us with systems and ask us to master them. We learn to jump at the right time, hit the mark, ask the right question in the dialogue tree, navigate the maze, push the block, kill the enemy.   On the surface, Papers, Please is a game with novel mechanics about document examination. You play the role of a border control agent who must ensure that everyone's papers are up to date, authentic, and match the immigrant. You are given a rule book and are asked to highlight problems with the papers by matching up a rule to an offending line or image. In a couple of clicks, you tease out contradictions, stamp the passport Denied, and call for the next and the next.  As the game rolls along, new wrinkles and rules appear and the documents become more complex. The faster you work, the more salary you take home to care for your family, so it behooves you to master the mechanics and become an expert agent who doesn't make mistakes and processes the line impartially.  Over time, you come to realize that the game is asking more of you. It puts you in situations where it could be wrong to follow the rules you have invested so much time to learn. To deny the passport of someone's loved one. To take a bribe. To look the other way for a local official. To detain people for money.  In other words, the game asks you, in a way I found very emotionally honest, to stop playing so well.  The first time through, I did my best to follow all the rules in the book, for good or bad. I played the role of a faceless functionary. It was mechanical in every sense of the word. But the second time through, I let my conscience be my guide. To my surprise, things played out very differently.  This is the best trick of Papers, Please. It makes you uncomfortable to play. It asks you to stop and think about the no-win situation it hands you. It rewards you for changing your mind.  One of the best games of 2013.

So you are a borders control officer in this simple looking game.  To begin you are checking passports - yeah that guys face matches his picture, passport number mhm... simple enough. Daily you are assigned new tasks, soon immigrants require further paperwork which all must be checked and stamped so you know it isn't a forgery. Then they require proof of vaccines as polio hits the country... then there are faces of the country's most wanted you must watch out for as well as doing your job.  The game becomes a test of your scrutiny and vigilance towards the documentation and dialogue as you approve or decline individuals and hope as you call 'next' that a little print out doesn't appear on your desk telling you why the last person's checks were incorrect.  You are monitored!  To add further problems, you encounter various characters coming through your booth. There is the chap who seems nice enough with his hand drawn passport but no you cannot just let through anyone! Then there is the guy who dumps a bomb at your window! Then there is the ever elusive order. It is up to you how you deal with this vigilante group. Do you support them with their promises to keep you safe or do you maintain your honesty and deny them their requests. At the same time there is corruption and you are ordered by your superiors to let certain individuals through against the rules.  At the end of every day you go home with whatever scrapings you made from bribes, rewards and efficiency at your work. You can save money by denying your family heat and food but they will get sick and you must pay for medicine.  This game for whatever reason is addictive! I enjoy playing it and am curious to discover all 20 endings and somehow unlock the endless mode. People complain about the price but for the hours you get out of it, it is not to be sniffed at.

(Experience: Made it to Day 28) (Time spent: 11 hours at the moment) (Bought price: $3.29 cdn)  'Papers, Please' is a simple yet addictive game that utilizes your abilities to follow the rules. You are an inspector, and your job is to DENY or APPOVE people who are trying to cross the border to Arstotzka.  Here's the twist ... Papers Please makes it incredibly satisfying to follow the rules and weed out the crooks, false positives, forged passports and other information. As you progress with each day, you get a certain amount of money to feed your family based on your efforts at your job. If you work fast, you get more pay. If you don't have enough money, your family gets cold, sick, or hungry. You want to keep them alive.  Bottomline: You should DEFINITELY try it out!

This game is compelling in a way I can't even describe because it is so different from anything I've experienced before. Essentially, the gameplay boils down to being a TSA agent, but the setting, atmosphere, and music somehow manage to turn that into something so much more. You find yourself doing to people what you would hate having done to you if you were attempting to get through security at an airport or border all because of orders handed down to you and the family you are trying to protect. Do you deny someone you know is going to do something terrible despite him having all the correct documents? Do you turn away someone desperate to escape a terrible situation because his passport expired a day ago? Do you invade a person's privacy to determine their sex? It's a strange position to find yourself in and all of these scenarios add an interesting level of morality to your decisions. You keep wanting to play to see what happens next, what rules change, and what people show up at your gates. The endless mode and the multiple possible endings in the story mode add to the replayability of the title, and trust me, you will want to know what else can possibly happen based on the choices you made throughout the game. Overall, it's a fun and very interesting game. 8/10.

'Papers, Please' is a 2D adventure game rendered with old school graphics that allows you to follow the life of a border inspector in the fictional country of Arstotzka. Your objective is to control the papers and documents of every person trying to cross the border and interact with the other characters you will meet through several days of work. While at the beginning the controls you are tasked with are pretty simple, later on you will recive new orders that will require you to examine the papers you are given more and more carefully, in an effort to let pass, detain or reject the right people.  'Papers, Please' features an evolving story: you will recive tasks or orders from several characters and your actions will reflect the final outcome of your adventure. The game itself has a total of twenty different endings and you can choose to replay whatever day of work you wish, should you want a different outcome.  Another important element of the game is your outcome: at the end of each day you will be noticed with all the expanses you can cover, especially the ones involving the well-being of your family or the opportunity to purchase automatic control systems. Neglecting some of them could bring an abrupt end to your career, as well as accepting money and gifts from the wrong people. Making several mistakes during your dury is also sure to cause you some trouble.  All in all, 'Papers, Please' is an excellent adventure game, with a simple but engaging gameplay and a branched story that offers a lot of replay value

A 2013 release that really stands out for its gameplay, Papers, Please is not for everyone. If you're looking for the perfect break from all the grindy MMOs and shoot-em-ups, this may be just the title you're looking for.  In Papers, Please, you play out the role of a border inspector working in a dystopian country. Each potential immigrant presents you with a set of papers that may or may not fit the rule of the law, and it's up to you to find discrepancies in the paperwork - and to occasionally let humanity win out and break the law to help others. It's a truly memorable game that you shouldn't miss if you have any interest in releases that help define gaming as an art form.

The game boils down to you scanning documents for inaccuracies, and approving or denying entry to various citizens of the futuristic world trying to enter your home country; Arkotsk. You were drafted into working there, and you and your family were forced to move to a new rent-controlled home. You are expected to pay for their food, heat, medicine, and other needs as well as a hefty rent on your measly salary as border/customs agent.   What's really cool about this game though, is that while at first you struggle with the simple basics of the 'job', it soon becomes second nature. Once you become a jaded ♥♥♥♥ at the customs office you start to notice weird things happening around you; corrupt guards, terrorist attacks, ethical dilemnas relating to your post, bombs, murders, and of course forged documents. If you haven't played this game, you're missing out. It's not the pretentious indie game you would come to expect. It was worth every penny and my playing time proves it. It's not some gimpy social commentary, it's a well-rounded game with a thoughtful premise and despite the outdated graphics you get something that isn't commonly seen in games today: style. Everything is sylized and despite the obvious indication that you're playing a game, you WILL be immersed after playing a few 'levels'. Like a good book, you will not be able to put this game down. Most games will get you emotionally invested in a character after several pages of dialogue if not more, but 'Papers, Please' masterfully draws you into each and every character with only several LINES. The weightiness of each situation is real, the consequence is real, and if you thought you knew who you were before this game I assure you that you will see yourself for who you really are after your first playthrough. Your choices actually have consequence, and the choices themselves are carefully constructed to test you. It's not just black and white, as you define who you are as an inspector you in turn shape your nation. It's literally nationstates: the game. I love it. I'm reccomending this game to everyone I know, it's just that good. As a puzzle game goes, this quirky thing is way up there with Meteos and Professor Layton. It can compete with the best of them. Don't play easy mode, play the way the developer intended. If you feel the time limit is too overwhelming for you, don't feel bad and drop this game. It's supposed to be overwhelming at first, but as time goes on you'll start to assess situations more effeciently (Like a real job! Go figure.) and it will simulate the feeling of 'becoming a cog' in a system that is seemingly out of your control.   PICK. THIS. THE F**K. UP.

I haven't played this game much, but so far I like it and would recommend it to others who are looking for something different. It's very much an indie game and it really is a 'job simulator' or a 'paperwork simulator' so you would think that it would be pretty boring. Well, as my teenage daughter said when watching my wife play, 'it's sort of boring, but sort of interesting.'  I think what makes the game interesting is the story of a working class man in a fictional communist country trying to make ends meet at his bureaucratic job that pays him peanuts. He's got his own problems to deal with keeping his family fed, warm, and healthy. BUt as he goes through the motions everyday of stamping passports, allowing or denying people at his checkpoint, he is confronted sometimes with other people's problems. What does he do? Does he just follow the rules of his employer/government and cover his own butt? Or does he sometimes break the rules when seemingly honest people might be in trouble and might need help from him? I think it's this tension that makes the game interesting. It's not always clear what is the right thing to do.   You have to have a quick eye and pay attention to details in this game since you can make a little more money the more people you proces each day. But if you make too many mistakes and break the rules, then your bosses penalize you. So you have a lot of incentive to be merciless to those who sometimes approach you for help. So the game sort of encourages you to be a cold-hearted bureacratic machine and makes it hard to do what you think is the right thing to help someone in need. I think that is part of the tension that makes the game good. You can let someone through who doesn't have the right paperwork and your bosses will give you a warning about that, and that puts pressure on you to not make any other followup mistakes or you'll lose some of the little money you make.  The pixelated, retro graphics that are in this game seem to be all the rage these days with indie games these days, and I honestly am getting tired of the trend, but in this case the visuals really work well because they enhance the bleakness of the setting of the game.  This is definitely a game to try out if you are looking for a different gaming experience, especially if you can get it on sale.

Have you ever wanted to work in security customs and border control? Have you ever wanted to be responsible for controlling who comes in and out of your country? This game simulates just that. It may use cheap 2D, 16 color graphics, but in a way, a game like this doesn't need to be fancy. All you have to do is make sure you follow regulations, make sure all citizens have the proper papers, make sure they have followed the guide lines (Expiration Date, proper photo, correct city information, etc.) Make sure no one passes that are not allowed in the country. This game tests your ability to remember rules and watch for inconsistant information on documents. If you think you would make a good borders patrol, then test your knowledge and skill with this game. It starts easy, but you have to remember more as you progress through the game. You not only have to watch for face versus photo and expiration date, but you also have to remember which cities are valid places to get papers as well as checking to make sure all fields are filled in. How well you work determines how much money you make to help your family. This is not so different from real life. Work well and do your job correctly, your family will be well taken care of. If you screw up, you and your family will be out in the cold.  'Papers please... this is not your face, this is expired, this is not the proper birth certificate, are you sure you're not female?'

Papers, Please is a simplistic masterpiece of straddling lines and juxtaposition.  Attacking the dark subject of oppressive, totalitarian/dictatorship governments isn't quite as depressing when done with broken English, cookie-cutter pixel-people, and hilarious immigrants. The impersonality of the character you play - a nameless border inspector - and his job - turning countless people away from the border - allows the player to make the character his/her own through imagination and the decisions made during the work-day. One playthrough you may be a mindless drone, dedicated to country and government, following every rule to the t. The next you could be a rebel, aligning with guerilla groups to thwart your evil government. Maybe you're an altruist, taking every opportunity you can to help the unfortunate people seeking to cross your border, even when it means your family may have to go without heat for a night. This is where the seeming impersonality of the game gives it another advantage; while you must remove yourself from many a situation when denying one entry to your country, while most of the game is based upon reducing people down to ID supplements and passports, accepting and denying as names and faces bleed together, you still have a family to take care of, and still make the occasional friend on the job, have an authentic connection with a person. And when most interaction is cold and impersonal, that occasional friendship means all the more. Deciding how to respond when a rebel group asks you to assassinate someone seems all the more important when the entire day was spent in a mindless tedium of passports and ID cards. Yet while you may not have expected it out of yourself, deciding to aid a drug smuggler when it will allow your wife and son to eat dinner that night suddenly becomes a very easy decision.  This is a casual game to slip into, but once you’re playing, it requires intense concentration, as you try to process as many people as possible in a given day while scrutinizing numerous pieces of paper for the tiniest discrepancy. It is a simple, mindless game on the surface, yet at its core challenges the player to consider human rights and the consequences of his/her decisions from personal to international scales.  I highly recommend this game. Among the multitude of indie titles available on steam, Papers Please provides a unique, rewarding experience sure to leave the player thinking.   Glory to Arstotzka, Glory to Papers, Please!

I have always wondered what it would be like to live in a Class-8 Dwelling in a country that has just emerged from war and reopened its borders and I have been drawn out of a metaphorical hat to be in charge of its wellbeing. Oh? What's that! Papers,Please!  This game was a very, very interesing addition to my everygrowing list of games I should shake the hands of the developers of (Needs a catchier title)  It is a game where you play as an Immigration officer who is the only one in charge of the ENTIRE border control. Which means you have a workload, You have simply a Rule book, The news and a transcript and must make the important decision to accept or deny entry in to Arstotzka, You must carefully assess each bit of their passport, Entry tickets, Work permits, the rules change daily and to keep on top of them all is a difficult task indeed! For example on Day 1 You simply look for the passport and if all the details on that are up to scratch they are allowed in! If you get it wrong 3 times money begins to be deducted from your pay.  That last sentence influenced a lot in me, you have a family to care for who only living in a Class 8 dwelling will not survive long , you must get through enough people in a day to pay rent, Food and heat and sometimes your idiot Son goes and gets ill and you have to buy Medicine... That idiot! It toys with your emotions, you want to let this person in to see their Husband after they were separated after the war, but if you do you will directly be at blame and lose pay and possibly a Family member... See why I like this game alot!  Also the tension is insane! You have so much to think about in such little time it is hard not to become overhelmed and hide behind a convenient pringles can!   I highly recommend this game, the Tension it creates in currently unmatched and the fun you get out of it is addicting, It is also fairly cheap for what you get out of it! With exellence in its Music, Design and plot it is a massive contender for Game of 2013! Enjoy a Class 8 Dwelling folks!

Congratulations. The October labor lottery is complete. Your name was pulled.  For immediate placement, report to the Ministry of Admission at Grestin Border Checkpoint.  An apartment will be provided for you and your family in East Grestin. Expect a Class-8 dwelling.     Papers, Please   is a beautiful little indie game by Lucas Pope, a gem that truly stands out in the ocean filled with Early Access Survival- and 8-bit 'retro' adventure games. The year is 1982, and you work as an inspector at a border security checkpoint. Dozens of people flow past each day, and you must carefully examine each person's passport and then either approve or deny their application. As days go, the game also gets progressively harder. Immigrants will be required to have more and more documents, and the payroll stays the same, yet you must also provide food and warmth for your family. Political backstabbing and tension between countries may also come into play, due to the 6-year-war between Arstotzka and Kolechia. I really wish there were more games like this, but unfortunately both creativity and originality have become rarer as time has gone by.   Glory to Arstotzka.

Good games have always had their advantages in different ways i.e.: graphics physics or even nostalgia, Papers Please has you manning a check point as people filter through.  The graphics and colors drab and muted, some of the controls are archaic. You indeed are playing the role of a low level cog in a socialistic structure. Every decision you make will affect the minute lives of the people coming through.  The colors making the room grow colder, the drawn out faces of people in quiet desperation eating away at you patients. But wait! It affects a lot more! You’re now faced with growing dilemmas, pressures, conspiracies, and the ever tightening time constraints, superior reviews, and unscrupulous propositions threatening your very family!  …Well some games have different advantages. Very few would actually sharpen your senses, test your resolve, and show you how and where the collective mindset ends every time. Everything about “Papers Please” will make you a better person than “superheronation” and “Crimson of Rose” (not that that would be hard to do). How can I resist ending this review with Glory to Arstotzka!

This is an award-winning game hailed for being innovative beautiful commentary.  Meanwhile, I found it alternately boring and frustrating, but never managed to find the fun. It is what I would consider an 'arthouse' game; I realize that the boredom and frustration are both features and not bugs, that the stultifying repetition of having nonsense shoved in front of you which causes you to consult a guide which there isn't enough room to open on your tiny desk to see if the information matches, is all a wonderful recreation of bureaucracy. I get it, and for people who appreciate that sort of commentary and a look inside that world, this game does convey that feeling. What it does not provide is entertainment value. So, I have embraced my inner philistine, and give this bold innovative game a thumbs down.

I really truly don't understand all the excitement over this game. It must be some sort hip indie game thing.  This game is frustrating, obnoxious, confusing and not at all interesting. You are expected to (literally about 5 minutes in) memorize several gibberish names of cities for each of a bunch of countries. Then it tests that by changing only one letter in the name (a 'c' to a 'k' for example), so you need to memorize the spelling as well. You COULD check the map in the rule book but this takes forever and your family dies due to you not making enough money per day. At the same time, you are to check a myriad of other things for validity, many of which are never made clear to the player. It never told me I had to check ID number for validity and I still don't know what makes an ID number valid or not. I had to google how to tell a man that he needed a passport as this wasn't adequately explained either and the game refused to progress until I dealt with it.  On top of this, you need to make sure the passport photo matches, which is a complete crapshoot considering the character portraits lack any detail. Usually at least once a (in-game) day the game tells me I was wrong just because I don't know what constitutes a good enough match.  And this is all just a few levels in. Supposedly it gets considerably more tedious and confusing. Becuase that's somehow an enjoyable game mechanic? You actually have to UNLOCK hotkeys from the storyline. What.  On the plus side the music is pretty great.   I'd never recommend it, but apparently I'm the wrong one and everybody simply loves processing paperwork according to confusing, obnoxious, unexplained beaurocratic rules. I simply did not enjoy it.  It's probably some sort of 'art' thing.

Let me share a brief anecdote:  Do you remember at uni etc, after having finished an extended question for maths, having got the answer wrong, and then having to sift through several pages of working to find where the error was?  Papers, Please is a very interesting game, and I can certainly see why it is so popular and well rated, but for me it felt like sifting through pages to find one small error. Once you get to the stage where forgeries are possible, there are all kinds of stuff you have to watch out for; incorrect copies of a variety of symbols, incorrect cities f4rom various countries, and so on. It's not so bad at first, but having to do this faster and faster to save your starving family, it gets very annoying to have to flick through several pages to check symbols and city names.  This is a good game, don't get me wrong, but it just wasn't my style. I found it too repetitive, and very hard to come to grips with in the first few rounds - my family died in three days because I couldn't process fast enough, didn't know what to look for. And later on, the fines get a lot harsher for the slightest mistake, you have to take bribes to survive and risk the fines, but simply missing one detail and getting a huge fine gets rather annoying.

Papers, Please or Red Tape of a Red State  I enjoyed this game and I certainly got my money's worth. It is executed brilliantly and the music, sound, scripted events and design are great. The bleak tone of a red state is presented well and should appeal to a child of the 80s who remembers the closing decade of the Cold War.  However most gamers in general may not enjoy the relentless bureaucracy; let me explain. Each in-game 'day' normally lasts 12 hours (about 10 real minutes) and your income depends on how many entrants you process (too many mistakes penalizes your income). In theory this is a good risk/reward balance and keeps things moving. In practice it gets pretty grueling.   If you don't have an eye and attention span for detail this game won't be very appealing. If you've ever worked a desk job it will feel very much like real-life work. On my second playthrough (achievement hunting) I actually found myself checking the in-game clock to see if my shift was almost over. That's when I realized I couldn't give this game a thumbs up to the general public in good conscious.  Lastly I do recommend this game to achievement hunters. It's not difficult, extremely inexpensive on sale and easy enough to get to 100% in <10 hours.  Glory to Arstotzka, glory to relentless bureaucracy!
