To be honest, I didn't know what to expect when I started playing 'Papers, Please'. Some friends of mine recommended the game highly and as it was on sale, I bought it. Though the concept behind the game is simple, you're a border cop who is to grant or deny access to your country to people based on the papers and other evidence they provide, it can get quite complex.  The first days of the game introduce new concepts at a fast but manageable pace, steadily adding to the complexity of your task. Though the concept may sound boring, it's actually quite entertaining due to the colourful characters that appear at your booth (some are humorous, some address real-life issues like human trafficking), the puzzle work involved, the cheesy coldwar era communist state setting and the 'reward' overview at the end of every day.  I've only played a couple of hours yet, but am really enjoying the game. Only drawback I have identified is that sometimes people with ok documents and motives blow themselves up after I've granted them access to the country. I've 'retried' these people several times and can find nothing wrong. Maybe these are scripted events to increase difficulty? If so, I would have gladly known about it, as I'm currently unsure what I'm doing wrong. Otherwise a very enjoyable experience.

It's funny--in the age of ultra-realistic graphics and sprawling even-the-kitchen-seek AAA titles, the games I remember most are often the games where I can do the least.  Here, you see people at a checkpoint, then try to keep your family fed and warm at home. People might invite you to post-workplace events ranging from the sordid to the friendly, but you don't go there. They might claim to have interesting lives, but you don't know for sure if you're lying. All you know is the documents they have, the stories they tell, and the regulations that dominate everyone's lives.  Strangely enough, I found myself loving this game's side characters, precisely because I had to imagine their lives, and also because their lives are so obviously more interesting than the task of comparing yet another passport number to yet another government-issued ID.   This isn't the most fun of gameplay (though, despite its similarities to a rather sub-par desk job, the gameplay is strangely hypnotic and relaxing.) But it's a fascinating narrative exercise, and experiment in empathy.  I got to the end of the game once after a few hours of gameplay, and I may not re-play it. But I also can't imagine forgetting it. This is an interesting little restrained story of the game.

Never did I think that a game with graphics that make MS-DOS games feel groundbreaking, a repeditive gameplaym barely any sound mentionable, shallow story and few objectives could be so good, This game really show that the sum is greater than it's parts. I don't know what is with this game but it is magical.  Basically the game is about you being a border guard checking papers at a border between two fictional nations. It all gives the impression being in some sort of eastern-European state during behind the iron curtain during the Soviet era. Your task is to either admit och reject those who seek to enter based on the papers provided and the requirements set by your superiors. You simply scan these papers for faults. You have to do this fast enough to feed your poor family as the time is limited and you are paid per person reviewed. All errors lead to a salary reduction. Sometimes you stand between wrong admitting a person who just wish to be with its beloved, sometimes to accept bribes and sometimes you choose between aiding a terrorist organisation or fact the consequenses of not doing so.  I suppose it is all the context of the game that makes the magic. You strangely enough get sucked into it.

LANGUAGE OPTIONS!!!!!  You pretty much get the idea from any other review about this fantastic, one of a kind game. What really sold me on this game was the ability to switch between languages. I have studied Russian for years and have never found a way to make customs/airport vocabulary fun or engaging in a meaningful way. Papers Please does just that, and the effortless and in-game language translation toggle is superb. I actually feel like this game was meant to be played in Russian given the bleak Soviet themes. I cannot speak for the other 6 or 7 languages offered, but I found that a replay of Papers Please (Докумктеы Пожалуйста) in Russian was as completely different and rewarding experience, one that I can actually apply in a real world setting. How many games offer that? Buy it! Ha zdorovye!

A simple game that, despite it being all about checking paperwork, is really a lot of fun. You get a strange sense of accomplishment anytime you detain a criminal or reject someone with incomplete paperwork. It's a lot of fun, but beware! If you have stuff to do, this game will take all of your time away! 4 1/2 out of 5!

I didn't believe it was possible to make stamping passports and cross-checking information tense but somehow Papers, Please has done just that. It's an indie game in every sense of the phrase, as the entire game was allegedly built from the ground up by a single man, Lucas Pope; that in itself makes it worthy of a look. While it won't appeal to everyone as it is essentially a point-and-click and others may find it a bit repetitive, I was pleasantly surprised at how involved in the game I became which I credit to the story. Additionally, twenty different endings to that story guarantees replay value and the branch-off save system makes it simple to explore them all. If it piques your interest, the beta is still free to download so you can see what you think.  Glory to Arstotzka

The thing I like the most about Papers, Please is that it makes no attempt to be typical. It is what it is, and what it is just happens to be a very captivating experience. Though simplistic, the level of intricacy involved in trying to be perfectly accurate during every passport inspection in the game is mind-boggling. A very enjoyable lean-back-in-your-chair-and-have-fun type of game in my opinion. The graphics are outstanding for the atmosphere of this game, and as you advance it does become rather challenging. I don't like using backgrounds with quick-references in this game, as it ruins the authenticity for me. I like the idea of really flipping through the pages of a book (in-game) looking for the references you need and comparing them to the documents presented to you. Feels really great. The addition of feeling the pressure of processing as many people's papers as you can possibly manage in one shift to earn as much money as you can so you can support your family is also great. You don't have vast expanes of time to sift through every possible thing there could be wrong about the documents or you simply won't earn enough money. That plus the fact that when you make too many mistakes your paycheck gets cut back makes this a nice challenge. It's intrigueing to realise that you really make a system and routine for yourself without really thinking about it. Some people say this game sounds like working an office job, that might be true for some people but I find it highly enjoyable! 8/10

Don't be mislead by the whole 'art game' thing. It has (more than?) enough gameplay going for it to be an actual game. This game actually is fairly solid at it's core, with interesting gameplay mechanics. You'll quickly be amazed by how easy it is to make mistakes in judging someone's legal documents and how many layers of control this game offers. It has more depth than meets the eye. It's great even at what it does. Do keep in mind that the aesthetics are a bit rough in this pixel art style and it remains to be seen how all things combined will influence the game's longetivity. But I've already had a good few hours of fun with this and probably will occasionally play some more. It's also the only game I know of in it's genre of 'border patrol' style gaming. Add to that random events like terrorist bombings, people you have/can detain for human trafficking and it's quite a cool spin on the simulation genre. The stalinistic setting is nice and adds to the overall experience. The low pay with a direct impact on your own family can be a bit crude at times, but it's a nice touch.  It does seem to have a bug or two on at least the Mac version where sometimes clicking doesn't register when calling for people to show their passports.

Papers, Please had me hooked for a short while. In a weird, yet fun way I would start it up, bob my head to the music, and pretend that I was 'going to work' again.   The game starts you off tame and picks up momentum, forcing you to remember initial tasks and methods while learning new ones each day that passes. I had great fun in these mini-games (if that is what you would call them) such as denying a citizen or finding that tiny discrepency that allowed me to use an X-ray and find that contraband or weapon only to have the poor person hauled away (most likely for execution).   However, for whatever reason I stopped playing and although I have thought about picking back up where I left off several times over the past few months, I haven't been able to get myself to do so. This is where I ultimately land with this game, that is, its fun if you play it and stick with it (and if you have an interest in this sort of puzzle-ish, organizational memory-game). However, if you allow any amount of time in between playthroughs that is too great, I think you'll find it somewhat tedious and difficult to get back into the swing of things. If I were to go back now, I'd have to basically re-learn everything from the beginning just to keep up with where I was when I left off - and this is not the most appealing thought, at least to me.   Papers, Please is unique and definitely well crafted. The gameplay is tight, the visuals have a pleasing, retro feel, and the challenge is definitely there for those that love to one-up themselves on a second or third playthrough. It just, for several reasons mentioned and not (as I'm sure I missed a few), doesn't hold my interest enought to want to actually play it - and this is why I'd give P,P a 7.5/10.   Maybe it's just not for me after all.... :/

'Papers, Please' is a mesmerizing game that presents you with moral dilemmas that test your loyalty to your family and country, your commitment to your work, your ability to show or suppress compassion, and your desire to rise above your lot in life to make a difference. The game designer managed to accomplish all this in an elaborately crafted branching narrative, told through a simple, though somewhat repetitive, immigration investigation game. It's definitely a game that will appeal more to the cerebral gamers.

I got this game in a bundle of others and for the longest time thought that it was a bit of a joke. Checking passport numbers? pictures? stamping card? oh, what incredible fun </sarcasm>  Then, I played it... Sure, memorising the countries, major towns, districts and keeping an eye on the date was a pain... but when sabotage, espionage, complicated underlying struggles of day-to-day life and the strange memory of my time doing similar things as an actual job... I am actually enjoying this game! hang on, need to scan someone for a bomb because their weight does not add up to their ID card. Their city matches, but I saw them earlier with a fake passport! I need to make sure I don't let a terrorist through or it might be me they blow up next! ACK! I didn't check the name on that last worker permit! After stuffing up the forged stamp on the other two, i'm getting my pay docked! Thank goodness i'm in with a guard who'se cutting me a slice of his bonus for my arresting folks with illegal info or I wouldn't be able to feed my family, pay for my sick mother-in-law's medicine or keep the house warm... I'm trying to save up for a bigger apartment too, but I doubt i'm going to get enough money after that incident with the secret sect I turned in...  It's not for everyone, but if you have a halfway decent memory (or a handy note-book like me) you will do well from the get-go. Work fast, focus hard and provide for your family...  Stay sly, work on the side and crack the code given to you be smart, keep yourself under the radar and don't get arrested. Day by day, you will face discrete small-world problems... but other days, you may find you help make the news!  This is not your standard game. This is a bit of a work-sim! I think this should be played in schools to teach kids to spot-check info quickly. There's a strange beauty to this game!  You won't believe it until you try it!

I liked the fact that there are multiple endings, depending on the decisions you make in-game. Many of those choices reflect the tension of compassion vs duty but the tension was never really pointed or pronounced enough for me.   I liked how the game was designed in such a way as to allow you to go back and replay a day differently. That gives this game tremendous replay value.  Overall, I highly recommend this ~ give it a shot because it is an entirely unconventional game with a unique story.

This is an excellent game that lives up to the hype. I'd seen a bunch of praise for it on gaming sites I respect, and finally decided to take the plunge for myself. I absolutely do not regret paying full price for such a great game in many respects. First of all, although not marketed as such, this is a fantastic detective simulator that will reward you for careful attention to detail. The sparse story is written well enough to evoke true emotion from you, leading to gut-wrenching decisions that force you to balance your humanity with your survival instinct. While the gameplay is fairly repetitive, the story is rewarding enough and the scenarios are varied enough that it's not really a problem (but if you're wary of the repetitive gameplay, you should still buy it, just wait for a sale.) While this game is not for everyone, if you're into puzzles, looking for clues, paying attention to detail and slower games that make you think, go ahead and give it a download.

Who knew border patrol could be fun? Well, I guess not necessarily fun, but it engages you in a way you wouldn't expect. Plus, it has a unique way of weaving a story, and several roles you can play in it. The choices you make impact the world in ways that might eventually come back to bite you, or might help you out in the end. On your first time playing, you have no idea if the choices you make are good ones. But you have to make them. And no matter what happens, you have to brush it off as best you can, because you're getting paid based on how many people you let in. And every ruble goes towards keeping you and your family afloat.

I rate the game Papers Please 4/5. Good.  If you can get past this game's terrible graphics and ugly colors it's actually pretty fun considering this is essentially a game that revolves around following bureaucratic procedures, comparing codes and other information between different simulated pieces of paper, doing other simulated paperwork and stamping people's simulated passports (and doing all this as quickly as possible and learning how that usually isn't fast enough).   The game has a good, detailed story mode plot and can end with any one of 20 different possible endings. This game (and its plot) appears to be heavily influenced by George Orwell but is also influenced heavily (as George Orwell was also heavily influenced) by Soviet Russia and its various border states. This game (which starts simple but becomes increasingly complex) is also often funny but in a very dry and tragic manner. For added replayability it also has two difficulty modes (one mode causes your character to be paid adequately while the other difficulty mode gives you inadequate pay). The amount of money you make affects your family who must be kept warm and be fed and if they are not, will suffer and die (in a sort of oregon trail style menu which says how poorly they are doing).   Ultimately, this is a desktop game which can be quickly opened and closed like a round of solitaire which tests your gameplay ethics in a situation which is, to say the least, full of ethical uncertainty and injustice. The biggest downside to this game is that it can get boring pretty fast (the ugly colors, the ugly graphics the 1 piece of music the game has, the paper-shuffling gameplay all contribute to this) requiring a break from it now and then. This is still a good game if played for short durations and a nice reminder of how bad it can be (even (if not especially) if you really try hard to be upstanding citizen) in a soviet-fascist styled nation-state. And it has dry humor. Don't forget the dry humor because that's a whole lot of what makes this game as good as it is. That and the really cheap price. No bugs.

A 'document simulator.' You review documents of an endless, dreary parade of people trying to enter your crappy country from one of its crappy neighbors, granting or denying entry as you see fit. Some sort of omnipotent oversight system penalizes you for technical mistakes. Or technical *cough*'mistakes,' since that last guy slipped you a $20, causing your finger to slip and hit the wrong button, of course.  An excellent diversion from the usual videogame moral dichotomy of 'to be or not be an (donkey is censored?),' where there's actual difficulty in making a decision. As you're usually some variant of The Chosen One, games have to find a way to let you keep playing even if you prove to be a total (censored, evidently) who no one would ever trust to do anything. As such, you're usually free to be as much of a (censored again) as you'd like, and some characters might scowl at you differently, but otherwise with little or no consequence. Or to chase the carrot-on-a-stick they included to try and get you to  not  do so. In Papers, Please, however, I feel they've done a much better job giving your choices positive  and  negative consequences. Do you help the rebels, knowing it could lead to your imprisonment or death? How about if it can lead to your  family's  imprisonment? Do you let a probably-not-terrorist trying to escape an even worse country in, if it means you can pay rent? Or that it could result in a demerit? Do you let your boss violate the rules he continually berates you with? Do you turn in the guy with forged documents, knowing he's probably harmless? Or just turn him away? How about if the guard promises to pay you for each person you arrest, regardless of guilt?  Most of these are not necessarily  that  questionable, I suppose - it's still just a game, basically restricted to what the designers intended, but it is quite a refreshing change from choosing to kill or save the Little Sisters, or selecting the Paragon or Renegade responses (and usually receiving an obvious tangible benefit, regardless of what Peter Molyneux promised you this time around). It's just pleasant to have a game give you pause for thought, rather than pause to calculate reward. Or figure out which of the things is going to actually make Commander Shepard say what you want him to. But in Papers, Please: Does your family go cold tonight?   Or do they go hungry, instead?

When starting this game, you might think it is a simple and fun change from your average game.  Until you are sixteen hours in and realise that being a virtual border guard has become a way of life, and you know all Arstotzkan immigration laws off the top of your head. It's fun and simple until you realise that you cross-reference passports with ID supplements with work permits without a second glance. It's fun and simple until you realise you know all issuing cities and can tell a genuine dimplomat stamp from a forgery with the corner of your eye. It's all fun and simple until    they find you helped the rebellion and then kill you.    Glory to Arstotzka!  The Actual Review:  The game is fun and is very easy to become serious about as it progresses. It starts off easily enough, making sure passports aren't expired and they are Arstotzkan citizen, but it becomes much deeper very quickly. I haven't gotten around to playing endless mode, because story is intriguing enough. When you begin, you want to let the poor immigrants in and help the people who need it, but you will not last long playing like this. To keep you and your family alive you need to be logical and uncaring, even to your family. Money is tight as well. My tip is alternate nights with food and heat, and those without. Only buy medicine when they are very sick. However, this game is a commitment, best saved for when you have time and effort to direct towards checking virtual passports.

Papers, Please is a surreal indie game in which you play as a border inspector working for the communist country, Arstotzka. The game is full of gray areas that force the player to make difficult decisions. The 'puzzles' get increasingly difficult as the game progresses, with more and more rules being put in place for you to follow. This game is not perfect by any means, but the pros heavily outweigh the cons.   The game starts with you finding out you had been chosen in the 'lottery,' and that you are now forced to become Arstotzka's border inspector. They had recently opened the border, so crowds of people who want to get in are large and unruly, with instances such as terrorism becoming a somewhat common occurance. Everybody who comes up to you for entrance to Arstotzka has a reason for going there, whether it be work or family. It is up to you to decide if they are fit to enter by checking their passports and other documents to make sure they are not counterfeit or missing completely. If you let someone in who doesn't have the proper documents, you will be penalized. This is where the concept of choice appears, as it is up to you to decide if you want to let the desperate people in even if they are not qualified. No matter your decision, the game makes you feel terrible for what you have done. If you let them go, you lose money that you need to spend on rent and medicine for your sick family, which results in a fail-state if it happens to often. If you deny them, you will have to see their hopes and dreams crushed as they discover they may not see their family again.    The game plays fine, but the repetitive gameplay gets old rather fast, so you will often have to take a break to avoid getting too sick of the game. The puzzles start off easy, but get harder as the game progresses. It is a gentle slope, so you will never feel overwhelmed by the amount of things you have to do. It is worth noting that you will likely have to do a lot of reading in order to fully understand how to play the game, and a perfect run is pretty much impossible. The more people you get through the more money you make, but if you go too fast you may make more mistakes which result in more penalties.   The art style of this game is interesting to say the least. People look deformed and sad, which fits in with the bleak setting of the game. There is nothing noteworthy about the graphics, but the gray and brown color scale of the game portray a perfect atmoshere.   Overall, this is a great game that really makes you wonder about the choices you make. The gameplay is quite repetitive, but the tone and setting of the game seem to always bring you back for more. This is a must buy for fans of surreal, atmospheric games.

Working at a job that deals with people's well being can be incredibly taxing. Your decision determines whether their lives continue in bliss or go up in flames. It's hard to stare someone in the face and tell them they are wrong, despite their best efforts. Papers, Please gives you the task of being a border checkpoint agent.  With that comes tasks such as checking passport information and following the rules set out by your company. Should you disregard those rules, you will be penalized and may end up losing your job, family or life. It's a very serious game of give and take with people who are honestly trying their best and others that want to game the system.  Most people will never experience such a scenario in their own lives, but this game truly hits home for those that work in public services. Being a doctor, nurse, clinician, phychologist or any kind of care giver can put an incredible strain on your mind. Maybe you gave the wrong advice, or your administration of medicine was done too early; hell, maybe you just looked at someone wrong.  It's never easy to hear a sob story and then deny someone a basic human right that you take for granted. Denying passports and reading that the person is upset can be stomach turning. You feel desperately bad, even if they should have just followed the rules.  Mixed in with all these moral quandaries is a plot about a corrupt government and a rebel group attempting a coup. You can safely ignore them and still have a satisfying experience, but delving into the complexities of the plot in Papers, Please reveals something interesting; maybe you don't agree with everything.  It's easy to be a dutiful citizen and get nothing in return, accepting that life is ♥♥♥♥ and clocking out for the day. It's difficult to stand up to oppression and change the face of the world. Papers, Please gives you an opportunity to see what that change can do and how you can be the catalyst for a revolution.  Or you can simply do your 9 - 5 job and get a decent paycheck and a nice apartment. The choice is yours, but no choice is easy. Thankfully, your save file can be split into branching paths, allowing you to experience every possible scenario.  The graphical style and music bring home the entire package. It feels oppressive and familiar. It looks like an SNES game, but it feels unique. It sounds like the USA lost the Cold War, but it also shows a country in disarray. It's bleak, but beautiful.  The only flaw would be that the game is a bit short. Also, that branching path system doesn't make all of your choices concrete. Having a system by which one mistake ruins your game would be more in line with the self-reflection the game is pushing on you, but I can understand that it would make the game feel incredibly daunting.  Regardless, Papers, Please is worth a play by anyone interested in a more realistic look at humanity. A job that most people never thought of and will probably never see first-hand. It's truly a modern masterpiece and well worth the $10 asking price.  9/10

You win the lottery, but this lottery is the one that gives you the job as the guy that checks the passports or citizen cards (if they're citizens of the best country in the world (glory to Arstotzka). Oh, and then you have to check for entry tickets, vaccination slips (we can't let polio-infected-filth into our glorious country), working passes, and entry passes.  You commit yourself to this job in order to keep our glorious Arstotzka safe...well, and to keep your family healthy and fed, but that comes second (obviously). Everything starts out nice and simple. You let the people with Arstotzka passports in. No other passports permitted. Sooner or later, we find that these passports have false information. Discrepancy detected. Now we have to watch for false information and deny them access to our glorious country. No exceptions.  Then, a terrorist attacks our border checkpoint and we find it's committed by a piece-of-filth Kolechian. They may not enter Arstotzka, and even better, if they try to pass through, they can say bye to their passports because they have been claimed by our Glorious Leader.  In this game, we have this job, wait, no... we have this honor of protecting our glorious country from unwanted degenerates. We are faced with unworthy liars and traitors who are only out to undermine the beauty of Arstotzka. They will try to have you join 'their cause', but their cause is something cannot be trusted. All of your trust, as is mine, goes to the glorious Arstotzka. Your 'family' (Arstotzka is your family now) may die. My neice ran away and I did not have the money to house her because I wanted new equipment to help me keep Arstotzka safe. Sacrifies will be made. People will die. You may die. Arstotzka lives on. Glory to Arstotzka.

Unique, funny and challenging, Papers Please is unlike any other game you've ever played. Set in a fictional totalitarian country, you act as a border checkpoint guard struggling to keep your family warm, fed, and healthy. Paid by the number of people you screen daily, you will encounter forgers, smugglers, and, even more morally challenging, people trying to visit sick relatives with improper paperwork. Do you call to your humanity, let them through, and risk your family's welfare and imprisonment? Or do you stamp denied on their passport to their curses and possible future retributions?  To say more of this very clever game would spoil it but it is a steal at the price for modern gaming ingenuity at its finest.

A true oddball game. Nobody would ever think that making a game about something a dull as checking passports could ever be made into a truly great game like this one manages to be. The story line has many branching points were you are given the choice to support the current weakened communist government or aid the well-meaning but somewhat foolish rebels, all the while deciding what to do with hordes of people seeking a better life in your “glorious” country.   How it handles the actual meat of the game is very well done, starting you off checking passports and adding to that slowly until you are armed with a sniper rifle, forcing people to do strip searches to make sure they aren’t bringing weapons or drugs, checking fingerprints and criminal records, all the while making sure that their passports, work permits, diplomatic papers, immigration pass, vaccination certificates and identity cards are all correct and not forged in any way.  This game will test your eye for detail and refine it down to a laser point. If you ever wanted to play a game that makes you feel as smart as Sherlock Homes without actually playing a Sherlock Homes point and click adventure game this is it.

A gruelling but oh-so-valuable look at the life of a customs official in a communist dystopia, Arstotzka. The intricacy of the level progression and the desire to treat people fairly when your family will starve if you don't process enough applicants each day creates a wonderful backdrop for moral decisions you may have never previously considered.  My advice? Play with a friend. Agree each day on who is checking what, and share the glory and the pain of serving Arstotzka. That way, when you cry yourself to sleep afterward at least you won't be alone.

A creative art style/theme that plays well into the 'Imperialistic' feel of the game. You really get the sense of urgency while trying to keep your family fed but also trying to accurately review papers.

Have you ever come home from work, hours of paperwork, filing, playing games on government time? Wasn't it exhausting? Would you like to continue in a fictional world? Then all hail Arstotska! While the game is very punishing, it also isn't too hard to get into the swing of things. As far as 8-bit games go, this one is a winner.

Look at this game. I mean seriously, look up the trailer or soem screenshots. Does it look like a great game? Not really. Is it a great game? Definitely.  Even though the 8-bit throwback style graphics are becoming overused nowadays, Papers, Please has a good reason for using them, and pulls it off well. The gameplay is literally the same as being a border guard. So, if this was labeled 'Border Simulator 1982' it would get a 6 or 7 out of 10. But it's not. The game is constructed in such a way that you want the very damn best for your little border guard and his family. You want to overthrow the corrupt government and you want to do the best damn job at removing Kolechians from the premises you possibly can.  How they did it, I don't know for sure. But this simple game of legal documents has more charm and personality than all of Activision's 2013 releases combined. You need to play this.  Glory to Arstotzka.

Papers, Please, from the outside, looks like a game that is rather cut and dry on what it's supposed to be. You are a checkpoint worker who approves or denies people access to your glorious homeland. This intrigued me as it was a break from the standard platformers and shooters. My first playthrough was not a noteworthy, but it surprised me with both the ways of identifying false passports, as well as the family aspect. The downside is that though the family aspect is a cool part to the game, it's also the most challenging, if the the most annoying part. With all due respect though, Papers, Please felt like a good game for the amount I paid for, and would recommend it to others. 8/10

'To his credit, Lucas Pope has crafted an experience where you truly feel like you are an immigration inspector. What may appear to be a fiendishly difficult and unfair game gradually becomes easier and more rewarding with each additional play through. Papers, Please may not be for everyone, but there is an abundance of content and charm to satisfy those who pass through the border and explore what lies beyond. Glory to Arstotzka!'  For my full written review, check out Critical Indie Gamer at  www.criticalindiegamer.com/2013/08/papers-please-review-pc

Offer me an hourly salary to sit and check information and data against other info and I would say that would be boring as hell. But make a low graphics game about it and sign me up for hours of play time. Amazing how mad I get when I miss a date or wrong issuing city and let a person through my gate. Then how ♥♥♥♥♥♥ I get cause my kids or wife is sick again and how much extra money they cost me. Don't they realize how stressful my job is and how if I try and do it faster I make mistakes and get fined. Oh and the rents been raised, sweet!   This is not a game but a second job, it will draw you in and make you want to do the best job you can so as not to anger the mighty leaders. Just when you get the hang of the new memo and procedures they want done, a new set of them comes out never letting you settle into a routine. I can not remember a game that is not a game but is a game that can trick you into playing it for hours.  I can't compare this to anything else but it is fun and worth the money, how someone came up with this as a game idea and what twisted upbringing led him to it I do not know but I enjoy it so far and am happy I bought it.

This game is ridiculously tedious with very little explanation of what you're actually supposed to be looking for... so essentially, a good simulation of what a government job is like. Every tiny detail can trip you up, so if you have a touch of OCD to you, this may be something you'll enjoy. For me, it gives me flashbacks to carding people for alcohol, but at least in this game they don't stick around and complain at you when you deny them. Story mode can be unforgiving of mistakes if you want to look over a few discrepancies for the sake of morality, so you may want to re-play levels to get a better understanding of the details before you move on.

Never before have I played a game so full of anxiety, mental agony, and inner torment. Never before have I felt so guilty, so tormented, or so relieved (while playing a game). I dendied a guy's passport, so he sent me $1000 dollars and I got arrested.  This is by far the most accurate simulation of cold-war russia on the market.

After the first 2 hours of playing, I found this game very interesting. 'Papers, Please' provides players with the most unique gaming experience since the launch of the PC Minecraft beta. Fascinatingly different, and surprisingly intense, 'Papers, Please' entertains in a way most games fail to even come close toward.   Simple, yet challenging, this game offers tons of replay value with new elements of gameplay being brought into the game constantly. Dark, mature and enriching, the cold war esque feel of the game is riveting and depressing. A fair amount of memorable characters make their way into a simple yet endeering plot that will captivate you. Elements of survival also help keep the tension high as the life of your family and those around you are threatened through various forces.  'Papers, Please' is unique, refreshing, grim and wonderfully cruel. You'll question your own morals as you are forced to hold the lives of strangers in your hand. Easily one of the best games of 2013. Wildly underappreciated.  My rating: A  Buy it now while it is cheap on Steam. Easily worth $4.99, or even the full price of $9.99

Amazing game and a little funny at times. The endings i got kinda ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off but if you like puzzle games that are fast-paced, get this game. It is something i would recommend to anyone. It is definatly worth it for 10$.

Wow. This game is awesome. It really truely makes you feel for a line of people trying to enter your country. I was surprised at the decisions I had to make, in the end, to ensure my families survival. I had five different endings, and only when they were safe, was I satisfied. With that said, the other endings are all interesting for different reasons, and I can see playing this for at least 20 hours total. Very original, and very interesting. Highly recommend.

You know, I knew this game would be as fun as it is the moment I saw it. I go through a lot of border crossing and I could always tell sitting in that booth, stamping passports in agonizing monotony was the best way to pass your days. In all seriousness, this game is insanely fun and dangerously addictive. And that theme music... My god, that theme music. I'm humming it half aloud while I'm walking down the street. People are looking at me funny. But no matter. They'll learn soon. They'll learn it's all for the glory of Arstotzka.
its a fairly simple game, but so addictingly fun. storyline was entertaining and i was invested from beginning to end. still trying to get a few more tokens. i highly recommend getting this game.
I feel like I'm back in soviet Russia and not in that bad way where I'm forced to eat dried bread and milk every morning.
Immediately engaging, deceptively intense. One of the more unique games I've played in a long time.

For a game revolving around paperwork, Papers Please proves itself to be remarkably engaging and oddly satisfying.  You are an impoverished civilian who has had the fortune of being selected to work in border control in the aftermath of War. Every day brings a new list of requirments and rules and failing to adhere to those rules may result in having wages docked - something you cannot afford given you have a family who depends upon you for survival.  Having said that, challenges arrive in the form of moral choices - will you have your wages docked so a woman can flee her ♥♥♥♥♥♥? Will you risk punishment in order to help a friend in need reunite with the love of his life? Or will you side with the rebellion, eager to bring down the corrupt goverment that runs your country?  Every day also bears the threat of having the border attacked by suicide bombers and terrorists, at which point you must take up arms and defend yourself and your collegues.  The game plays smoothly and offers a genuine challenge as the levels progress. Some of the NPCs are particularly memorable and the game will offer several moments of humour, horror and sentimentality.  I didn't expect to enjoy this game nearly as much when it was reccomended to me, and is a game I heartily reccomend in turn.

You'd be surprised how addictive it can be to stamp passports all day.  The game does put you in moral dilemma situations where you either save a person from being killed or prevent your family from starving, but you can't do both.

This game is weirdly addictive. It is easy to understand and it leads you in nicely, but it gets quite hard rather quickly and it kinda forces you to make difficult ethical decisions that have serious consequences. Lots of endings, I have only discovered a few so far.
One of the best games of 2013 (and not only for me...)!

First I was a little confused, but it keeps you entertained and things can change fast, sometimes you get requests for something, either you do it and get in trouble or you don't and stay happy....I love it!

Absolutely brilliant and hopelessly addictive. I spent weeks at work talking about my family and their unfortunate deaths only to confuse everyone utterly and get quite the reputation... Honestly, everyone should play this game (especially 'non-gamers'), it's a wonderful example of just how far excellent story telling and challenging game play can go.

I've only played this a little so far (4-5 'days' in the game), but it is really addictive. Each day adds complexity to your job as immigration officer at the border of some ficticious cold-war era country. The feeling is sad, totalitarian, hopeless. You're lucky to have this job, and your family has been put up in one of the ritzier concrete apartment blocks, where I'm sure there's only three rats instead of the normal ten. As the days progress and the government allows more entry with more fluidly changing requirements, you have to ensure that the documentation people present adds up. Names need to match, documents must be issued from the right place, do they have the right ticket, is it stamped and dated properly, etc. It's a seriously messed up brain game for adults! Oh you'll laugh your backsides off at some of the comments the people make, like trying to bribe you with tickets to the strip club. For the price of a cup or two of coffee, this is totally worth a few hours of your time if not many more.
So addictive.  Everyone should buy this, just because of the sheer dystopian life you are leading in it. The stress you are under, the desperation to keep everyone alive and happy... it is mental.

Papers, Please. An inetersting concept. You play the role of a man working an immigrant checkpoint. It's your duty to allow people who have all correct documentations through said checkpoint. It's alos your duty to deny those with contradictions in said documents. Or those missing documents. Or those with contraband and weapons. It's also your duty to stare at pictures of naked people who look like men, who turn out to be women to check their passport's aunthenticity. It's hard running a check point station.

Really good game, but not worth £7 it lacks in replayablity and can get you uninterested really quickly but if it is 50% or more off then i would really suggest picking this game up! so im giving it a thumbs up

My favorite indie game of 2013. The core concept sounds boring but it actually keeps your attention well with it's increasing level of difficulty and some rpg elements. As it's in the steam sale I would 100% recommend the purchase.

This is exactly my type of game. This game deals with global relations, from the eyes of the 'common man,' who has been given a slight amount of power. With the power to deny or grant entry into Arstotzka, you make choices to either better the state, or yourself, or perhaps even the immigrants, with all decisions ending in consequence. Arstotzka, a socialist state, has both elements of new technologies, mixed with the glory and look of the 'old world,' and I love it. This is a fun game, with all types of challenges, and I would definitely buy it.

Got this game when it was in beta. It is an interesting perspective into a militarized or police state. The toll of being an immigration worker and wanting to help people, but also wanting to do a good job. It takes quick mental reflexes and a good memory. Overall, it's one of my favorite games ever.

A brilliant little game. A moment in game history and, like Gun Point, an outstanding Indy game. Short and sweet, with a solid foundational game mechanic and a great style. It was much more fun that I expected. Actually, I put off playing this game for some time after it was receiving a lot of positive press. I was not quite sold on it being 'fun' game, and it sounded on paper maybe a bit too cerebreal or possibly even boring. It is neither. Don't put it off. Play this game.

This game is deceptively fun...It starts out slow (with good reason) and like in real life your choices early on can REALLY screw you over...even if your doing the right thing. A dark color pallette works well for this game, and the straight forward concept makes it easy to jump into, but at the same time the game does a great job breaking the monotany of passport stamping by throwing curveballs at you (no spoilers). And of course, just when you think you've got a handle on checking d.o.b, gender, home country, work visas, etc, etc, you have to start cross checking more documents.  One particular mechanic that I'm thrilled by is how the timeline is handled. You can jump back to any previous day and branch a new story-line to see different consequences instead of having to start all over again. I don't know how many times you can do this, but even just once is nice, as opposed to starting back from day 1 to see how different day 29 could have been.  I hope to see more from this developer in the future.

Papers, Please is a strangely addicting game that starts out fairly simple at first. You man a checkpoint at the border and have to check immigration documents for validity and decide on if they meet entry requirements or not. You get citations for making mistakes, and there is a lot of unrest happening at the border outside of your station. You have to move fast, because you are on a per-visa pay basis and have to feed your family and pay rent.  Worth it.
Very good. A brilliant game with a great storyline. Cannot flaw it in any way, it is genuinely a masterpiece!

Omg. Amazing 112/10 score  First off i would like to say, any one reading this who missed the whole 'point and click' tag up above please go away. This is not the game for you.   Day one, you won the lottery! Not the money kind of lottery, you won a job! You get to run the new crossing point into your country! They country has been closed for 6 years from others.(How come we dont have that? Lottery for awesome jobs?)  Anyways. So right away, you feel some really good country pride. Either saying to people 'HEY! WELCOME TO THE COUNTRY MAN! SO HAPPY FOR YOU TO SEE YOUR FAMILY AGAIN AFTER 6 YEARS' or you're yelling at people 'GET THE HELL AWAY FROM MY COUNTRY'   Right when you feel like you're doing a great job, someone got by you and there is a terrorist attack with guns and bombs and you can't help but to feel like it's your fault. I mean, you let them in didnt you? Then there are more terrorist attacks. Then people start trying to get you to join a revolution, and you think hey! Thats something to do if i get bored. You start feeling split between your country and the other people.  Then people start giving you stripper cards. Then Drug money.  Serial Killers. People looking for lost loved ones. Then bribing you to let them through.  And you dont know what to do any more. You have to pick your own side. What should you do?   20 different endings to the game are possible, without having to restart it.  This game had me mad, happy, teary eyed and confused. Everyone should buy this game.
Interesting game.
I like this game but its a small game and its sorta pointless but it can be fun! 4-5!

This game... is brilliant in its simplistic elegance and innovation. The boldness of its developers decision to grapple with some very real issues and their moral dilemmas. The concept, story & atmosphere convey so much in such a simple platform I was stunned by the depth that the game already achieves by day 3. The intensity and oppression of the game's premise really starts to get to you if you take the time to think about what you're doing. Are these people spinning lies with a honeyed tongue or are you the judge of their fate? Will it cost them their freedom? Their lives? Having heard stories in real life from mentors who lived through the core years of the Cold War behind the Iron Curtain, it is distrubing how the game brings them to life.  Papers, Please is a gem, that is a perverse, masochistic kind of fun in the most dystopian way. A stunning 10/10.

Papers Please is an excellent example of an amazing Indie game that could be considered Best game of 2013 with contenders like Bioshock Infinite, Last of Us, GTA 5. and in my opinion i believe papers please is better than all those shooters.  Papers Please in the end is an amazing experience for everyone, either making you look like a good guy to all civilions or or and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to everyone you come across. You see people come and go and make some new friends, and new enemies. Papers Please is an excellent PC which could be considered Game of the Year for people who play it. I would rate it 10/10 2nd best game of 2013 in my opinion.

Would you belive me if I tell you you will enjoy being a public servant being employed in a pseudo-comunist Rusia's immigration checkpoint? You better do, because this what this game is about, and it's ♥♥♥♥ing amazing. You can start njoying the perfect made screen which you play in, which consist in the cabine of the checkpoint, the aerial vision of the outside with all the queue of people waiting for pass, and your desk in which you have to carefully read the documents each citizen gives to you. Do you think this is boring? Tell me the same when you have limited time in a day and you have to check the expiration date, the issuing city, the photos, the gender, the validation of each freaking detail on the documents, and other things. You better do it fast, because you get paid for each one you decide right, and you will get nothing if you fail in your decision. By the end of each day, you'll have to manage your salary to feed and keep your family alive, and the game gives you a lot of choices based on moral or your personal preference. Do you want to arrest everyone you can so the guard that works with you pays you a small amount of his bonus? Do you maybe want to help an order that truly wants to clean the government of corruption? It can cost yourself or your family the life depending on the decissions you make, and you have more than 20 alternative endings. Enjoy being a public servant and, trust me, this game is more than it seems. Glory to Arstozka!  Me creerías si te digo que te vas a divertir siendo un empleado del gobierno que trabaja en la aduana de una pseudo Rusia comunista? Más te vale hacerlo, porque de eso va el juego, y es buenísimo. Puedes empezar gozándote lo bien hecho que esta la pantalla en la que juegas, que se conforma de la cabina de la aduana, una vista aérea de toda la cola de gente que quiere pasar, y el escritorio donde deberás revisar cuidadosamente los papeles que quienes vayan pasando te darán. ¿Crees que eso es aburrido? Dime lo mismo cuando vayas contrarreloj en un día y tengas que comprobar fechas de caducidad, ciudades de procedencia, género, fotos, la validación de cada ♥♥♥♥ documento que te den, y otras cosas. Más te vale hacerlo rápido, porque te pagan por cada persona sobre la que decides correctamente, y no te dan nada por cada una con la que te equivoques. Al final de cada día, tendrás que distribuir tu salario para alimentar y mantener viva a tu familia, y este juego te dará un montón de opciones basadas en la moral o en tu preferencia personal. ¿Quieres detener a todo el que puedas para que el guardia que trabaja contigo te pague una parte del bonus que le dan por ello? ¿Quieres ayudar a una orden secreta que intenta de verdad limpiar tu gobierno de corrupción? Tu vida o la de tu familia podrían estar en peligro según las decisiones que tomes, y tienes más de 20 posibles finales diferentes. Que disfrutéis de vuestro trabajo como funcionarios y, creédme, este juego es mucho más de lo que podría parecer. ¡Gloria a Arstozka!

Papers, Please is a hard sell, after all the sentence 'Eastern Bloc immigration official simulator' sounds anything but fun, let alone something that will maintain interest. Yet despite this apparent handicap, the game is totally engrossing, as you decide who can enter Arstotzka - and it really is a matter of life or death in some cases - and it poses so many questions about the gamers' ethics and morals.  Even though it seems to be a drudgery sim, with you doing little more than stamping passports for the duration, there's several storylines that run through the game and a sly streak of humour amidst the oppression and the dystopian greyness that stops the game feeling grim.  It may not be for everyone, as the game requires you to concentrate on the papers in front of you as well as keep a good memory of the nations and cities around you, but this gives Papers, Please an old school charm from the era where taking notes would get you through a game successfully, so if this is up your proverbial street this is a game for you. Be warned, though: you will be humming the theme tune for days.
a game that shows u the value of ur rl job. 18/10

Papers, Please is a testiment to the fact that a video game doesn't have to be 'fun' to be important. Papers, Please accentuates the mundanity of a run of the mill desk job in which the player is told exactly what to do by your superiors, and punished for not following the rules exactly. The game presents a lot of interesting scenarios in which the rules feel more like a grey structural outline for the player to either follow or bend a little bit in order to make meaningful, personal decisions. I found myself, on many occasions, stretching the rules to do the morally right thing, even if my cold-hearted superiors would vehemently dissagree with my actions. Papers, Please simulates being human in a very profound way.
10/10  Glory to Arstotzka This is truly the best game ever made, and I'm not just saying that because I'll be killed if I don't.

I saw this game on sale once and said 'how stupid a sim about being an inspector. What a terrible concept.'  I was wrong, so so so wrong. This game is a brilliant and clever social commentary. Papers, Please asks you to make moral decisions. Buy it and you might just learn something about yourself

Absolutely loved the game. I went into it not expecting much and I was blown away. The originality of the game is superb. I love that the game sucks you in and I can't wait for more from this developer.

you pay money to work how stupid is that

Something truly unique. This is a great argument for gaming as art, but I'm reviewing on the game itself and not what it represents.   The game is repetitive by nature, but that does nothing to make it less enjoyable. It will pull you in, it will have you obsessing over minute details, you wll become frustrated, and you will master paper pushing. This is a game and an experience that everyone should try.
You are buying this if you have a soul. Or a brain. Glory to Arstotzka!
Awesome game, highly recomend it to any gamer looking for something diffrent.

A wonderfully simple concept for a game that can prove very challenging with the mass amount of information required to process. Becoming more familiar with the game and it's mechanics makes it significantly easier to play, however it doesn't detract from the game whatsoever; it just adds a great feeling of accomplishment! Twenty different endings based on what actions you take add tons to the replayability of the game. Great pickup, I look forward to sinking many more hours into it!

This game is absolutely amazing, I can honestly say that its the BEST game i've played in a very long time. Since I purchased this game I havent switched on my PS4 once! This is what a game should be like, its not all about good graphics, its about how much fun the game is, and Papers Please DOES NOT dissapoint, in ANY way. Highly recommended to everyone.

On the outisde it seems like a monotonous repitition of stamping papers, and at first the game may also feel that way as well. HOWEVER, the more days you go to work the more complicated things become. People ask of you favors, you make errors and it costs you (and your family) money. Everything you do begins to have side effects, you may accidentally let a killer into your country and the next day there will be a headline about it in the daily newspaper. It's a fascinating game with 20(?) endings. You can take you and your family almost anywhere in the game. Whether your character is a die-hard loyalist, or even a revolutionary is entirely up to you!

This game is great! The concept seems quite boring - check people's paperwork at a border - but it really is enjoyable. Although the gameplay is repetative, it changes enough to keep you working and thinking. There's also the pressure of trying to get through as many people as possible to earn money for your family, which, along with the increased pace later in the game, really adds to the thrill.

A really nice game. It looks quite boring, but i really like the way the dev's balanced this game. There is a pretty depressing atmosphere in this game, that makes you really go into the 'sovjet' era ;) 7/10
Best Indie Game I've ever played, Strategic, makes you think, and has some comedic value to it as well. A bit of replay value, worth more than 10$ IMO

94/100. When 'simple' means great.  Pro: - Addictive gameplay. - Learning curve not straight as it may appear at a first look. - Great atmosphere sustained only by short dialogues and a few lines of text. - Always running out of time (or this is a cons?).  Cons: - I've already played it.  Recommended to everyone who are not scared from (a great) C64 graphic style and looks for something different from the average AAA title.

Excellent game with greater immersion than most non-pixelated titles.

What an amazing game with such a simple concept. I really didn't think I would play this game as much as I did after purchasing it. But logged over 30 hours of just having so much fun with it. The replay value is phenomonal if you want to unlock the achievements, and there are a lot of endings!  Absolutely worth it to keep you entertained for hours. Love this game. Thought it would be a simple game, but boy was I wrong. Not to say that it is completely hard, but you gotta be really careful with what's going on. Very nice.

If you've ever been curious what it is like to be a Russian border patrol worker this is the game for you. It presents many ethical dilemmas, and really does feel like being trapped in an excessive ever-changing beauracracy (which is a mixture of fun and frustrating). If you go into the game knowing this it'll be fun. But don't expect it to be fun, otherwise you'll be sorely disappointed.

This may seem like a plain time management game, but ... wow, it is well crafted! This really lives up to its promise of simulating a communist immigration inspector job ... moral choices both overt and subtle, steadily piling up democracy, and a perverse (and fitting) sense of humour. If the concept appeals to you, this is a must play!

Papers, Please is an enjoyable game you will never get tired of. It is such a simple game to understand. The controls are beyond easy and the flow of the game and story is GREAT! I recommend this to gamers who like to play games that don't always have to involve complex controls or amazing graphics, this game can run on any system.  This game requires concentration. It is what you will mostly need in Papers, Please.   5 OUT OF 5 STARS!

Papers, Please is a game that answered a lot of questions for me. The main question is: why do people break the law? And this game illustrates it perfectly. Not only does it do this, but it has the best morality system in games I have ever seen. Your choices actually mean something, you have power over other people - but mainly because it's actually integrated into the gameplay. Almost every few people that come by, they give you a reason why you should let them through even if they have the wrong stuff, and you have to decide whether it's good enough. You also have your own family to think about, so you can choose to make your family happy or make your comrades happy. While you do have all of this power, the game doesn't fail to remind you that, despite these choices, your position is actually quite terrible. And it doesn't hesitiate to rub it in your face when you get a bad ending. TL;DR, buy this game and learn why people are corrupt.

This game is extremely original and awesome, as I expected when I bought it.  It's so simple and yet so challenging! Some reviews say the game might feel repetitive, but on the contrary, I find it actually so fascinating it's hard to pull the plug once you've started, at least till one of the many many endings! I must also say that as a 20th century History geek, the setting of this dystopia really pleases me.  I just wished I sucked less at being a spy... Ah well!
Brilliant. I thought that it would be boring but - IT'S SO GOOD.
One of the most unusual games ever. Masterpiece in '1984' style.
Do you enjoy dystopian document thrillers? Of course not… It's tough to explain why poring through documents in a Soviet-esque customs booth circa '82 is fun, but it IS. 5/5
Love this game.

Manning a checkpoint and stamping visas may not sound like gripping gameplay but Papers, Please somehow manages it. With your family on the brink of starvation, political trouble brewing and a cast of characters whose lives you briefly glimpse (and possibly permanently alter) the impetus to be alert and make the right choices is very strong. It's a very hard game to put down.  The graphics may seem basic but they serve the dual purposes of paring back extraneous detail to help you concentrate while simultaneously reinforcing the dreary Cold-War era atmosphere. The moral quandaries you frequently find yourself in (you can barely go a day without being offered multiple bribes for a start) don't usually have clear right or wrong answers. Indeed, whenever I lost (often) I didn't get the impression it was because of any moral failings on my part, just making choices (or mistakes) with harsh consequences.  On the subject of losing, this game has one of the best save systems I've seen. It saves at the end of each day so that you can go back and restart from any day of any playthrough you like. You can go back and fix a mistake you realised from two days ago, or try something different or whatever you like and it displays it all in a way that is easy to navigate.  I'll finish by saying that this game might not be for everyone but I have personally loved it. If the idea of a game that's a bit different, that will make you think, that can actually draw you into the life of a poor worker stuck between a rock and a hard place, this is definitely worth a try. It won't break the bank and it will definitely leave you with an impression.

Papers, Please is a interestingly fun game to play. When I first seen this game, my initial thoughts was that it would be boring but how wrong I was. You take on the role of an immigration inspector that controls the flow of people entering. Among the many people entering, looking for work are hidden smugglers, spies, and terrorists are rampant. Taking a look at the provided documents by travelers and the Ministry of Admission's primitive inspect, search, and fingerprint systems you must decide who can enter Arstotzka and who will be turned away or arrested. It takes time to look through the documents and then cross checking them with the book and instructions you have been give to decide if you will approve them passing or not. A really different and interesting take on something for a game. Brillient game to play and have fun with.

I won't lie, I picked it up just because the title and the idea of the game made me laugh in a twisted sort of way. This game surprises you by actually developing a pseudo-story line halfway through and is a nice bit of mental exercise along the way.

A really great game. Visual and retro music but a completely innovative concept and design. Rather challenging and enjoyable. Don't let the visual and your preconception fool you because this is a really great game. Even the music that maybe strikes you at first but then you will find yourself humming it and wanting to hear the real deal over and over, specially the 'victory theme'.  There are so many things that can happen in the game that you will never get bored, even though your 'work' seems a lot like this. There are so many events that nets you over 20 possible endings with good and bad ones. Even the npc's gets your attention and empathy. Although it may seem the contrary you all the time need to make decisions that will affect yours future and the future of the people involved, and sometimes even the nation.  So to sum it up: a funny, enjoyable and creative game that will hook you.  Glory to Arstotzka!
The country is called Arstotzka. 10/10 GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!

So... you're working as a border control agent? All you do is check their documents to make sure they're legit? Oh, and if they're not you can deny or detain them? How exciting! That sounds like work, not a game.   I know it does, but it freaking works! Such a boring and pedestrian sounding concept that shouldn't be fun, but it is. For the most part, each day adds new 'things' you need to be on the look out for. As you get further into the game, entrants take longer to process just from the sheer number of documentation you need to check. But you better check it fast cause you're on the clock and your family needs to eat.  Your morals will be tested and you will get stressed out. And you will make mistakes. And they will be your fault. But you will still have a blast playing the game. Do yourself a favor and get this game.

A fantastic way to test your morals as you decide whether you want to save money for your famliy or help out strangers in need at your job of a customs officer. I cannot find anything wrong with this game. It is incredible.
wonderfully fun game. Beuracracy at its finest. if it's on sale, a definite good buy. glory to arstotzka
I would have to say this is one of the best indie games i've played to date. You can become so easily attached to games with such little features, Shout out to Jorji (A character in the game)

I honestly don't know how to describe this game.. The whole point of the game is to deny or accept immagrants into a fictional communisty country during the 1980s.. ((Think Russia with heavy border control)). It sounds stupid and look stupid.. Though playing 30 minutes in and you just can't stop. Something about this game and the story it presents will keep you hooked until the final day.

If a 'Dystopian Document Thriller' sounds like it might be enjoyable to you, it will be. As Yahtzee said, 'this game makes paperwork fun.' You will be engaged not only by the intricate story, but by the tough daily decisions you have to make (which give this game a complex morality system), and even the mundane task of checking documents as quickly as possible for any sort of discrepancy.

Papers, Please is possibly the most fun you can have in the most mundane setting.  It's 1982, and after the six-year war between Arstotzka and Kolechia comes to an end, the Grestin border checkpoint opens, reuniting families and allowing the safe passage of all sorts of characters. As the checkpoint inspector, it is your duty to approve or deny people based on the documents they have and the details therein.  Not only does Papers, Please immerse you in the fascinating world of excessive bureaucracy, but it forces you to make moral choices throughout, determining the fate of travellers and immigrants, aiding or hindering subversive elements, all while ensuring the survival of you and your family.  Such is life in  Glorious Arstotzka

This game looks surprisingly simple, but is surprisingly difficult as well. What seems to be just stapming papers, quickly tirns into a web of espionage, terrorism and smuggling. A very good game, which will keep you busy for longer than a lot of the so-called 'AAA' titles out there. Must buy.
The most entertaining game about paper work that I've ever played.

If you hate this game, then you also hate America. Your job in this game, is to decide who is allowed to move freely in your country. Half the fun of this game is that you get the privilege of being a cold callous bureaucrat, a corrupt official with his finger in every illicit pie. For a change, you get to be the one giving everyone the business and not the one looking down the business end of such and such thing!   You can also be kind and benevolent and let every person through who has a sob story. Just know, that no matter how you choose to play this game, you (your character, not 'you' yourself) are the most miserable scum of the earth and you're damn lucky to have a job!     I will not lie, there are a few bad things about this game. You need to remember/learn a set of arbitrary rules that are subject to change at the drop of a hat. You're pinned to a small desk where important things are sometimes hidden below unimportant things. You might have to read the newspaper! You might have to see something that you cannot unsee. Anything helpful to you is in a book that you might have to read more than once. All of these qualities make this game confusing but at the same time real. If any of this sounds like too much work, I feel sorry for you. Unless you're some kind of movie star, you should already be used to this sh*t by now.   If I haven't listed everything awesome about this game, it's because I only meant to relate half of what's so good about it; the other half you must discover for yourself. Also, it's $9.99! I could've eaten ten double cheeseburgers for that price, but instead I chose not to feel like sh*t. Buy this game. Click the button that says 'ADD TO CART.'
What can i say about this game... more than GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA! it's decent..... 10/10

Honestly, when I try to descibe Papers, Please to my friends, it sounds like the most boring thing ever. And yet it's fun! More fun than a paper-pushing sim should be. It's challenging, and it includes one of the most realistic moral choice systems in any game. It's not a question of good or evil; it's a question of following the rules. Do you follow the rules and hurt some stranger's life, or do you break the rules for them and hurt your own life? These are the questions this game has you make over and over again. It's great, and you should totally buy it.
Great Game its alot of fun if you are into this type of gameplay. I would give it a 8/10.

On the surface, Papers, Please is not a game you think you'd enjoy. I mean, who wants to do paperwork in their free time?! This game, however, makes mind numbing tedium fun again! Each day in the glorious nation of Arstotzka brings new challenges and hardships, looking to make you and your family cold and hungry, and it's up to you, a lowly border guard, to keep the nation safe from threats and terrorists, looking to upset the balance. Instantly addicting!

Papers, Please is a game that really, I didn't expect much from it. I bought it and thought, 'Looks fun to pass the time.' And then I started playing it. And let me say, I am impressed with how much this game holds. Set in 1982, you play a man who gets a new job and has to keep his family safe, healthy, and alive. Or, you don't have to. The game changes depending on the choices you make. The story, the news, and almost everything changes after the choices. It's really interesting and I enjoy playing it. I recommend it.

The most fun way of playing this game to be a souless ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ like me.

In soviet Arstotzka, the game plays you!  Explaining the premise of this game really doesn't make you want to buy it: Who would really think that playing a game where you work at a Soviet nation's border station would be challenging, addictive as well as humorous and immersive? Add the fact that this game has the graphics of an early 90's game and it's surprising that anyone has even bought this game. It really is something I've never seen before, even the genre is somewhat hard to describe: It's a 'real time puzzle' game combined with roleplaying elements.  The core gameplay consists of checking people's passports and ID's and other various documents before you make the decision of giving entry or turning people away. It is really challenging and fun. And by challenging I mean 'makes you want to rip your hair out if you haven't lost it from the stress already', at least with the 'no loading allowed' playstyle that I employ.   You have to process people as fast as you can, but making mistakes will also cost you, so you have to balance the speed and the precision. After every day of work, you get to spend your earned money by feeding your family, paying the rent and heating bill, and if things are going well, you can buy upgrades for your toll booth. But there's never enough money for everything after the beginning, unless you're some kind of border guard savant.  It starts off easy: Check if the customer has a passport, if it has expired, if it has been granted in an authorized town and if the person is identifiable from the picture. Foreigners you must turn back. Next day, foreigners are allowed. The next day foreigners and natives both have to have a different kind of extra document to pass and you have to cross-check the information with the passport as well as if the information checks out on it's own. Before you know it, your desk is cluttered with all sorts of papers and you have to remember three faces of criminals that you can't let pass and a couple of names who you have to pass, while shooting people who try to do terrorist bombings at the border.  You find yourself screaming at the screen: 'What?! No way was that entry pass a forgery, you've got to be kidding me! Where the hell is that document? Who was I supposed to let pass and why?!' Things will get desperate soon enough, and maybe you'll let a missing document slide if the customer has some 'incentive' to let him/her pass. Oh, stop being so high and mighty, my son was very sick and I needed the money!  The roleplaying is intriguing as well. There are some really desperate people at the border trying to get you to bend the rules and you will be faced with the decision of either doing your job, or the right thing. Dereliction of your duties will first result in notices from your supervisors and then you will get fined, but you find yourself thinking: 'She'll get murdered if I decline her Visa, and it's only a 5$ fine if I don't, so maybe I'll do it just this once.' You can also team up with different political factions, which have real consequences. There are 20 different endings so the choices matter.  Papers, Please is proof that an excellent game doesn't need a marketable premise or top-notch graphics. On the contrary, it might allow the freedom of focusing on the gameplay aspects that truly make a game great. I know I haven't played this much yet, so this praise is to be taken with a grain of salt, but this might be one of the best games of 2013.

Way more addicting than you would think by looking at it. You basically play as a Border check inspector in a communist country in 1982. Gameplay is just looking at people's papers and giving them the red stamp or the green stamp. But so many little stories and side plots come up and keep the game interesting. There are also more and more rules added on every in-game day so it gets harder to pick the right stamp. There's like 20 different endings too, so replay value is pretty good. Moral choice aspects are here and they are organic. The game makes it really hard to be a good person. Yeah you might be easy on a person and let them through because they'll die in their country otherwise, but then you'll get cited and oops now you can't afford food for your family that day. Great game for such a simple concept.

first time i played and reached the third in game day, then i couldnt seem to get past day 4, so i gave up and came back the next irl day and started from day 2 in game. well i kept on playing and playing and the next second i noticed it was 30 mins later and i had gone way past day 10. i recomend this game and if you get stuck, leave the game talk to someone or get something to eat or drink then come back re-try from the previous day and i can assure you that you will get back into a rythm. Plus the story is very good for a game about a boarder checkpoint.
Great thinking game. Emphasis on thinking. This is not a game for all. Not action based like most games. It took a jump, and will pay off in some eyes. A pioneer in my opion. Innovative.

Really fun and 'different' game. Almost an RPG element between balancing your 'budget', keeping family healthy/alive, and spending money on work upgrades.   If you can get this on sale, I would highly reccomend it. I'm sure plenty find it worth the full price- and I could certainly see that. Either way, great game!

This game was fantastic.  You wouldn't really expect visually inspecting the customs papers of artistically low-res nobodies to be so engaging, but Papers, Please makes you stop and think, feel, emphasize, with the people passing through a fictional customs checkpoint in a fictional totalitarian state almost as casually as it has you also put them through full body scans to verify sex or check for drugs. It's truly a unique experience.   I haven't yet played through to every end yet-- a lot of the decisions you make on your 30 day journey have a big impacts you can't fully see. It's a beautiful, emotionally involved game, but even transcending that is the pure joy of being an efficient cog in the Arstotskan bureaucracy. The joy of this game is basically inexplicable, I can only ask that you give it a shot.   And hell, it's on holiday sale!!
Forget everything you know about pushing papers, and enjoy this crazy weird game that has no right to be as interesting and fun as it is.
A very unique and immersive game, focused on atmosphere and consequences of your choices.
Unlike anything I've ever played.

Who knew that work could be interesting, and that over 50% of all the people entering a country are totally sketchy? Great game, somehow.

One of the most unique games I've ever seen, and it does a terrific job delivering its narrative through its gameplay.  GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!

Originally thought it seemed like a bit of a giggle, 4 hours later I was grinning from ear to ear because my neice went missing because I didn't earn enough. Next time I'll deny my mother-in-law her medicine. A truly deep political satire.  Just one more turn....

Definitely an engaging experience. A unique game, you'll spend your time poring over documents and comparing names and dates and other info. It gets complicated fast, but you'll catch up before too long and be fine.

My definitive Game of the Year for 2013. Everything about this game is so great. While it may look dull and repetitive on the front, there are many different kinds of stories going along, with you as the person who says what happens. With many options and 20 different endings, this is a must-buy.
Do you like dystopian document thrillers? What? No? Well, um... Screw it, just buy this game.
