Basically, it's a game about border control. Doesn't sound that fun. BUT IT IS. Good variety, plotline, characters and decision making within it.  I can't do it justice without allowing you to play it first... well worth the price.
This game deserves a GOTY award. waiting for part 2

Life as a boarder control officer isn't easy, and boy, does this game hit home. I'm not sure what I was expecting with Papers, Please, seeing as it was on sale when I got it and I knew little to nothing about it. I was pleasently surprised to find a charming, yet dark and depressing, game. The art style is unique and it fits perfectly with the sound effects and very little music the game has. The gameplay is easily graspable, fun, and challenging at times, even a bit saddening. It's a simple game about a heavy topic, and it tells a wonderful story which, depending on you, could end not so wonderfully, or just as much. Using the 'DENIED' stamp is very gratifying for some reason, and the responses can be quite amusing. Do a good job and you get a 'better' apartment (read: more expensive, you never get to see your apartment) and can afford heat and food and medicine for your family. Do poorly and your family might starve to death and you might eventually get arrested. Take a bribe and you might get arrested. Be honest and you might get arrested. Played this game when it was in the beta and absolutely loved it. It's amazing how such a boring idea like being a checkpoint officer can make such a fun and engaging game. For the small download size and lack of amazing graphics, there's so much content packed into this game with a in-depth story that can take a sudden turn at any moment depending on what you do. That man you just let in could have been a spy, maybe he's helping a secret agency to overthrow the government and you're now part of the conspiracy, or maybe he really is just a guy coming to work. You can only really know if you say the magic words; Papers, please.
This game is very addicting and surprisingly good. You shall be amazed at how looking over documents is extreamly entertaining.

The story is excellent, in that the story is about you, a poor working stiff trying to survive day-to-day, and the things that happen to you as you push papers for a fascist state.  The mechanics of your paper-pushing are lovingly implemented in the game. Everything about the game makes you feel the right way - the music, how you are shown the guards, how you are shown the civilians, the way the game makes you feel about stamping a visa, everything.  The game is challenging. You are constantly presented with choices, and thinking too long about any of them means doing a poor job and most likely getting your pay docked.
Climate and music are the best! One of not-so-many great games with good replayability value. After finishing this title you'll be suspicious at every airport.
A fantastic little game. the story takes unexpected turns and is brilliantly written. The gameplay is way better than you would imagine. Addictive, funny, fantastic. Buy it now.
This game is silly. And Horribly addicting!

This may seem like a plain time management game, but ... wow, it is well crafted! This really lives up to its promise of simulating a communist immigration inspector job ... moral choices both overt and subtle, steadily piling up democracy, and a perverse (and fitting) sense of humour. Satirical, entertaining, unique - all this things can be said about Papers, Please.   You play as an inspector at the border control of a fictional totalitarian state and have to manage your job as well as providing for your family by paying the rent and buying food and medicine. During the story, which lasts a maximum of 31 days depending on how you play, you will have to process dozens of people trying to gain entrance into Arstotzka the country you live in.   You will have to thoroughly check their passports, documents and statements in order to detect any discrepancies. The tasks and documents to check get more and more complicated throughout the game and you will have to face different dilemmas in the game, e.g. allow a woman to enter the country without her having all documents and risk a fine or will you deny her, but at the same time dooming her as she is ill and will die without proper medical treatment.   You should play the game if you are open to new unique experiences and do not mind the graphic which is not up to date, but fulfills its purpose and kind of gives the game this late 80s-early 90s look which fits perfectly. 8/10

Great indie game, fun and challenging mechanics, nice story. Later levels really make you feel the pressure: make a mistake and you get a warning ticket, get too many tickets and your family will starve or freeze to death. That's cold, man. Also, can't get the theme out of my head. Eternal glory to Arstotzka!
It makes you think, your family? Or theirs?

Definitely not something you'd call a 'fun' game, but it's certainly interesting. Multiple endings (20 in total) and a reasonably variable plot make things interesting, but it's doubtful you'll want to replay this. Can be completed in 4-10 hours, depending on how many times you replay days to compensate for mistakes. Big shout-out to the save system too, as it allows for branching saves to grant the freedom to experiment.

Glory to Arstotzka! You are a border passport agent in one of the most unique and inventive games I have seen in years. It's challenging enough inspecting every form as the number of forms and things to inspect increase on a daily basis under the increasingly onerous regulations. Under the surface is a surprisingly human game pitting your moral compass and the regulations of your government against the lives of the people in the checkpoint. Make too many mistakes and it may cost you and your family's health and maybe your life. Your choices matter as the game can end in a multitude of ways.   You will grow to hate the sound of a dot-matrix printer.

What is there to say about such a strange experience.....   I most certainly enjoy this game. It is odd though. I wouldn't so much as to say this game is super fun.... how fun can searching through documents looking for descrepensies really be? More than it sounds, that is for sure.  I started out thinking ok.... this is weird but I will give it a shot. Glad I did! Surprisingly addictive and simple. You start off kinda slow and gradually you find yourself flying through the rulebook, laying down the laws, and shutting people down! Making alliances with the guards to make more money by detaining people, great.   The more people you process the more money you make. You want to be quick but you don't want to overlook details and send someone through with false documentation, hello citations! You want to be quick, thorough, and precise. You want your dear family to live do you not? Then you must work. Hard.   My son died cold, hungry, and very sickly... will play again!

It gets a bit tougher as you keep going, you get confident and thats when you slip up. The look of this game is great, I cant wait for a sequel or an update. I highly reccomend this game.
GLORY TO ARZTOTZKA

You stamp passports to let people in to glorious Arstotzka. Sound easy right?  Make sure face matches. Make sure height and weight matches. Make sure they have proper identification. Make sure they have proper paperwork. ...A bribe? Press the detain button. Search them. Make sure they are not smuggling goods in. Please present your passpo-  He's jumped over the barricades! Quickly now! Grab key! Use box! Grab gun! Load gun-!!!!!!  The terrorist detonated bomb strapped to body. Glorious Arstotzka now increasing security measures.  Help the resistance? Memorize paper and hand back. They'll come through later. Allow them access?  Jorji... you again? I have to call police. Yes, friend, I am sorry.  Day is over... now, should I feed my family or provide them heat? They are starving, cold and sick... they are all about to die.  All glory to Arstotzka.  This game is a document checking simulation. There is nothing fancy about it, but it will keep you playing to find out what happens next.  My tip to you comrade?  ...  ...  ...Deny those ♥♥♥♥ing reporters.  Glory to Arstotzka.
Throw your morals out the doors, proper documentation is all that matters. A game about finding discrepancies across forms doesn't sound fun but it is, incredibly so.

An addictive game. Such a simple concept, let them through or not. But you have to send so many people through a day so your family can eat. Your family gets sick and cold. Your family members die. Mess up and let a forged document through and there are penalties. People beg you for entry, but you muset deny them.   The game starts in 1982 (at least mine did). The graphics are minimal, but it adds to the game. I liked that the creators kept a old game feel to it. I liked that more and more is added each day in game and you go from a simple accept/deny booth to accept/deny booth with access to guns, detaining, and searching. You become friends with certain guards and certain people.   I definitely recommend it!

Papers, Please puts you in a setting, time, culture and gives you something that imerses people no matter where they are: a job.  It never breaks character while you play, consistantly reminding you of your place and what your supposed to be doing--it's your job to be repetitive and to notice unwelcome changes.  As a checkpoint officer, your tasked with checking the passports of people coming in to Atrokska. After awhile, your job gets difficult with the fluxuations of rules tailored to the changing laws of your country.  Through it all, you must remain consistant, vigilant, and aware. ...unless you simply don't want to.   Papers, Please offers you multiple oppertunities to stray from the mundane repetitive nature of your employment, but simple choices could lead to huge outcomes; bad and good.   This title can offer you immersion without the player entirely realizing it, and indeed they do this very well. Before you know it, you step back from your PC wondering why you just spent three hours looking at passports.  No, seriously.  Passports.   In a game.    I suggest this title to anyone looking for a quirky but satisfying sim. Glory to Atroksa.

There's something immensely gratifying about a game that rewards you not for cutting corners, cheating the system or getting one over on someone but for being accurate and efficient. Papers please is a game about spotting errors and mistakes, essentially an elaborate 'spot the difference' set in a humourous dystopian communist soviet state. Just like its solid unwavering theme tune, this game is a masterpiece of simplicity and good game design that really builds a sense of tension waiting for the inevitable citation slip every time you give someone the go-ahead to enter. Every time I start it up and the relentless plodding theme tune begins all I hear is yet another nail being hammered into the coffin of big game studios. Glory to Arstotzka.

this game is as soulless as its name automatically denotes. Papers please is quite obviously, a game made for the german populace: it is a simulator that sets itself to be as boring as possible. Visa Inspection simulator, to be precise. and although the screenshots and srt style look blocky and grey, the way the game is played will definitely make you think. It is not as adrenaline-inducing as Ground Zeroes or as hyper realistic as Arma, but it still provides a story and offers the player enough immersion into the game where it actually may affect the gameplay individually. simple terms, the game changes the more (or less) involved you are in it. you spend an 8 hour day inspecting and stamping visas and sending people into the country or back out the door. the rest of it it pretty much covered in the tutorial. it sounds boring, and for many, it is. but for those that like a game that requires a bit of wit and willingness to have fun in it, this is definitely a winner.

Want to review alot of documents? No? That's what I thought as well, until I got Papers, Please.   This game is incredibly unique, It's hard to find anything like this. This game is not for everyone, if you prefer action packed games, Papers, Please is definetly a game that you will not be intersted in. Every little detail in this game matters, and missing something, or taking too long to make sure you don't miss anything, could kill a family member. Another thing about this game is choice. Many people will give you the wrong papers, But will try and bribe you with Money, or a sad story. You can let this people in and risk your job, or just follow the rules and deny them. There is no right answer, and you can never be a good person. It's deppressing, and while they have 20 different endings, none of them are really a 'Good' ending. I've played through this game 6 times, and I still have fun with this game, but I doubt many people will play this game more than twice. I would recommended this to many people, but don't be expected a standard sort of game.   8/10.   Glory to Arstotzka.

Omg. Amazing 112/10 score  First off i would like to say, any one reading this who missed the whole 'point and click' tag up above please go away. This is not the game for you.   Day one, you won the lottery! Not the money kind of lottery, you won a job! You get to run the new crossing point into your country! They country has been closed for 6 years from others.(How come we dont have that? Lottery for awesome jobs?)  Anyways. So right away, you feel some really good country pride. Either saying to people 'HEY! WELCOME TO THE COUNTRY MAN! SO HAPPY FOR YOU TO SEE YOUR FAMILY AGAIN AFTER 6 YEARS' or you're yelling at people 'GET THE HELL AWAY FROM MY COUNTRY'   Right when you feel like you're doing a great job, someone got by you and there is a terrorist attack with guns and bombs and you can't help but to feel like it's your fault. I mean, you let them in didnt you? Then there are more terrorist attacks. Then people start trying to get you to join a revolution, and you think hey! Thats something to do if i get bored. You start feeling split between your country and the other people.  Then people start giving you stripper cards. Then Drug money.  Serial Killers. People looking for lost loved ones. Then bribing you to let them through.  And you dont know what to do any more. You have to pick your own side. What should you do?   20 different endings to the game are possible, without having to restart it.  This game had me mad, happy, teary eyed and confused. Everyone should buy this game.

Papers, Please is an ambitious game that takes the concept of a dystopian society and the strict controls that are placed on the borders and tries to make it an interactive experience. It's times like this I wish there was the option for a neutral rating on Steam because whilst there are a few positives to the game there are a lot of negatives that I personally disliked about the game.  Starting with positives the nitty, gritty pixelled style of the game is a throwback to the 1980s where this game takes place and adds to the charm of it. It's really great but the downfall of this is that sometimes it can be hard to see if there really is a discrepency that you're expected to pick up on. The music in the game is fantastic (when it plays) and adds to the atmosphere of a society controlled by a strict regime. I literally cannot fault the music; it's perfect for this kind of game to be honest. The save system works on a timeline basis meaning you can go back and replay days and basically create a split timeline which is something that I appreciated as it meant I didn't have to go back and play through parts of the story I'd already seen. It's innovative and something I would urge other game devs to follow this format for other story intensive games with multiple endings. There's very little humour to the game but one of the characters, Jorji, is a light in an otherwise bleak world and it made me smile whenever he popped up into the booth. Cobrastan is best country.  Unfortunately what does let the game down is that after the 2 hour mark it begins to feel more like a job than an actual game and the fun factor completely dies off. Perhaps this was the intention of the game but if you're like me it ends up killing whatever motivation I had for the game. If reflecting the boring job of border control was the game's intention it did a great job at that. The moral choices that you're expected to make sometimes feel cheap and I felt no sympathy for the people I turned away (in fact I took great delight in detaining anyone I could much to the horror of my boyfriend who claims I'd ruin many people's days if I this was my real life job). I'm a sucker for stories that pull at my heart strings and leave me feeling depressed but Papers, Please failed to illicit any of those emotions from me. There are two main stories that you can follow and one is dull and boring whilst the other has a little more action orientated. The former just drags an already dull game downwards. Even whilst playing through both storylines there's very little difference between the two other than choosing to take someone's passport or not, etc. Some variation and more consequences would have been fantastic.  If I look at this game as a game I genuinely cannot recommend this unless you delight in sorting through mounds of paperwork. As a statement this game reflects life in a country being torn apart by conflict and the strict regimes of an oppressive society great (although it's still not fun to play). I'd recommend buying this on sale because you're either going to love it or turn around and absolutely dislike it to the point where playing feels like a chore.

I once saw a Let's Play of this game and immediatly fell in love with it. 'Papers, Please' is like nothing you have ever seen before, you play as an Immigration Inspector deciding the faith of the people in the communistic country of Arstotzka.  You have to carefully check passports, work permits, vaccination papers and so much more and carefully decide who you will accept and who you will decline and do not take your decisions lightly either! everything you do will impact your game.   Besides immigrants you have have to help your family survive the cold winter in lonely Arstotzka and deal with tons of unforseen events such as terrorist attacks, rebellions and serial killers, make sure you make the right decision because it could be your last!  What might turn you on? - Multiple possible endings, strive for the best one! - Incredible atmosphere, the music and colours of the game truly set the right mood. - Wonderful characters, you just WANT to help some of these people, you will care for them, you will betray them.   What might turn you off? - Heavily text based game, it involves a LOT of reading. - Hard, even though the premise might be simple,   this game is really hard and most of your family won't live through your first play through.  In the end, would I recommend this game? Well if you prefer heavy action based games, super intense RPG games or multiplayer madness shooters then no. Do you love the indie type game, those games that are just so weird you love them for being unique and giving you that playstyle no other game could ever give you? Then hell yeah!

I'd heard of this little indie game a long time before I finally played it, and I was glad I did. The game isn't particularly complicated, it isn't a drawn out adventure to defeat evil. It's simple in it's premise: you get a job in the fictional country of Arzstoska as a border customs checker. You need to check the passports of people passing through, allowing entry to the people with the right identification and denying/detaining those without. But the game soon becomes lot more complicated and complex, and soon you have to decide whether to let people through to be with their husbands, despire the fact they don't have all the right papers, or to help stop a wanted criminal, or detain people who haven't done wrong, just so you can get a little extra money so you can get food, warmth and medicine for your family. It's a great game, with loads of replayability. It's fast-paced, complex, and has you questioning your moral choices. Brilliant.

I honestly have no idea how it does it, but this game is probably one of the best I've ever played. Incredibly simple, so small that it downloaded on dial-up internet in three minutes, and absolutely brilliant. Despite the fact that your working a deadpan, repetitive job, in a world where everything seems to be ruled by a communist government, with a colour palette that's as bland as the inside of a public school. Yet despite how awfully dreadful the game seems as a concept, it's incredibly engaging. With multiple story paths, excellent game mechanics, a visual setting and soundtrack that creates the perfect atmosphere, 'Papers, Please' has the highest replay value of anything I've ever gotten my hands on and will forever remain in my list of favourite games.

'Arstotzka so great, passport not required.' If only, Jorji, if only.  The demo for this game was so good it made me get a steam account just so I could play the full version. I get twinkly-eyed when talking about this game, and I talk about it to anyone who will listen. Such an aware and astute political comment. The game some how manages in that little cube checkpoint to be all about human relationships, and how compassion and revolution relate, and a million other themes. Even if you don't play compassionately, I think it's still true that it's about compassion. So there's a lot of heavy material, a lot that I still think about after months. But also it's funny and light? I think it goes back to the charm of relationships and interactions. There are so many potential stories in this game, you see so many people come by the checkout, and you are also confronted with whole states, but somehow the story stays small and personal too, in a way that replicates real politics. I could go on. Just play the game, you'll think a lot about states and morals and rebellion and empathy and power in the process.   That music too! wow!

Papers, Please is a game that sounds incredibly boring in a nutshell.  You're a border patrol passpor inspector. It's stylistically low-key (though quite pleasing), simple, and the rules are available to you on-screen at all times.  But somehow the game makes me feel anxious and alert the entire time you're playing it.  Did you check it all? Did you get it right? Every approval or denial leaves you with gritted teeth for the 5 seconds it takes the entree to walk away. As soon as you hear the mechanical whirr of the fax machine printing your mistakes, you kick yourself for missing a detail and keep going.  Really engrossing. Fun to get all the endings, and the way the game saves files makes it incredibly easy to correct previous mistakes allowing you to skip over the need to completely start a new file. A very underrated feature.  Much enjoyed.

Something that struck me about 'Papers, Please' is that it isn't a fun game. It's a paperwork simulator that feels unrewarding and almost painful, but for a good reason. Everything about this game adds to the story from the dreary atmosphere to the sympathetic characters, and it's this context that turns the dull mechanics into something truly tense and deep.  Possibly the most appealing aspect are the choices you make. The ones you make are both big and small, but you only ever have a few seconds to decide on something that could change the lives of the people you meet. The game genuinely gives the chance to confront these situations, and is more worthy of a game than most because of it.

I came to dread the sound of a citation being printed, meaning that I'd made a mistake. In doing this, the game does a great job of destroying your empathy for the potential immigrants, then brings it back for just long enough for you to feel like a terrible person. Paper, Please is unique. It somehow looks dated and dull at first glance with the retro-like graphics. Yet, suprisingly, it manages to transform a mundane inspection job into a simplistic game with addictive gameplay and high replayability value for the moral choices and endings.  Never have I felt so satisfied admitting immigrants only to find out some of them carry bad influences into Arstotzka, your country.   In some days, you will be shocked to see some fake documents and crazy people that will force you to upgrade your inspection tools.  The difficulty is about right. It eventually ramps out a little bit faster than you think, but it is still not too difficult.  There are some memorable moments when you realize you've made some mistakes and then *boom* someone dies because of your error.  It features two modes; story mode and endless mode.  The flaw that I can find is the music is not too impressive and repetitive.  Well, at the end of the day, this game is worth buying.   Score: 8.5/10 'Cool Job. Glory to Arstotzka.'

On a 0 - 10 point scale, I would proabably give this a 7.   The game itself, story, setting and that stuff, is surprisingly good and addicting. I have just gotten the perfect ending, which you will not be getting right away when you play for the first time. I usually don't write reviews, but I felt like I had to now. Because the reason this doesn't get a full 10, which it very much deserves, is what happens after you get the perfect ending.  You unlock 'Endless Mode'. I thought that it was a free-roam with customizeable conditions and such. But what it really was was an online challenge mode, with four different game-modes, not customizeable in any way. Heavily leaning towards online-competition.  So for the people that enjoyed the game and would like to keep playing normally after the story finishes, are screwed. There is no way than to redo the story again. Which will get just annoying in the end.  As I said, 7 out of 10.

For some reason this game is a lot more fun than it seems like it should be. You are in charge of a customs booth either allowing people into the country or denying them based on rules that change as the game goes on. There is also a story that develops as you progress through the days and the choices you make can change your entire future. You can play through this game several times and not get the same ending as long as you make slightly difference choices of course. You don't have to sit there and play the whole day, you can play just a little and come back whenever you want. You could even come back a year later since the mechanics are simple and it's more processing the immigrants than quick reflexes and memorizing controls. Highly recommend it and I think everyone should give this a shot if it seems like something you would be interested in trying.

Had been looking into this game for a while, so I caved in when I saw it for sale. So I was somewhat aquaited with the game when I first started paying it, or so I thought. This game threw so many curveballs my way I felt like a major league baseball player at the plate. I found myself creating a routine to checking informaiton, weighting the pros and cons of letting a single person through, and worrying about my dying son (he died) all in one day. All of this can sound like an overwhelming experience, but it felt perfectly balanced throughout the days in-game by working towards more and more to check everyday. You truly feel like you are deciding the fate of Arstotzka with every person you let through and every decision you make. With there being 20 different endingd you are bound to at least get 3 or so of them through a single play through, and the game offeres you a chance to go back to a certian day to change the outcome.   TL:DR If you would like to have an impact on the fate of a single country in the form of an under paid and over worked border checkpoint inspector, then this is the game for you. Lots of fun.   Glory to Arstotzka! ~In loving memory of my son

Papers, Please is one of my favorite games of all time and I have finished it atleast 5 times and plan to keep on playing it over and over. I bought the game on GoG first and then bought it on Steam. I think this is a one of a kind game, its smart, yet deceptively simple. The dystopian oppresive regime setting of Arstotzka (clearly influenced from Soviet Russia) is very bleak and life is tough. If you can't afford to pay for heat or food, family members will die. If you can't pay for rent, then well I guess it's game over!  I think this game is very much fun to roleplay, I would suggest doing the first playthrough being 'good' and helping out people in need, and just acknowledging the oppression of Arstotzka. Then it's fun to do another playthrough being 'bad', where you are honorable to Arstotzka. Still, I think this is one of the best indie games I have ever played, and I would really like a sequel if possible! (even though the dev stated that there won't be) Glory to Arstotzka!

It's really both a satisfying challenge and a tasteful throwback.  People who wonder what was awe-inspiring creations in the mid-80's...here you go!  Secretly wrapped in this retro-creation is a layered and complexed detective-sub-game. Challenge yourself to catch the fakes and determine if they are criminals who deserve state-mandated justice or individual-based compassion.

Fantastic game with a great deal of charm. The addicting game mechanic is entertaining and certainly worth playing, and the story is filled with humor, excitemnent, and lots of emotion. Few games have been so simple and yet so immersive. With the achievements and alternate endings, it has some good replay value, although maybe not enough for some people. As a whole, I would without a doubt recommend it!

Papers Please has become one of my favourite games i´ve ever played. Its gameplay is pretty simple and the idea behind it too. I never imagined that the story behind such a simplistic game could be so immersive and interesting. I know many games say that but the story in this game is really influenced in the way you play it and how good you are in it. So i have to say that i mostly got bad endings in the beginning. The game isnt very long but once you get to one ending you can start at any day you want to get a different outcome, and let me say there are so many endings! It really has a high replay value so it makes fun for over 10 or 20 hours. I can highly recommend this game for this low price. Have fun while playing!

Grab it on sale and enjoy the few days of gaming diversion it provides.

If you told me I'd really enjoy playing a game where you check passports to make sure they're valid before letting someone through a border, I'm not sure I'd have believed you. Having played Papers, Please, I can tell you that it's awesome. The game is so much fun and will make you laugh out loud at times, while also offering an enjoyable level of complexity and challenge as the game progresses. The visuals are good, the gameplay straightforward, and the length of the game perfect - not too long, not too short, and definitely worth re-playing to take the story in a different direction.  Highly recommended. Will certainly be gifting this to friends who don't have it.  Glory to Arstotzka.
